componenttext: This is Scott Moore. We do not. Our volumes are sold in the Tennessee and Transco primarily. And so the issue on Transco does has directly impacted Anadarko.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Credit Suisse.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to start with a bit of a slide, which you may not be able to answer. But you mentioned the good depth on the AP markets and what's of interest on the gas side. Obviously, you've got quite a large gas footprint in terms of production in East
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to start with a bit of a slide, which you may not be able to answer. But you mentioned the good depth on the AP markets and what's of interest on the gas side. Obviously, you've got quite a large gas footprint in terms of production in East Texas, North Louisiana, Marcellus, some of the Eagle Ford and Mozambique sort of come up. Is that the market for gassy assets deep enough in general for you to do something more transformative with the debt burden, which still seems too high?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me address part of the question and ask Bob to address part of the question as well. If you recall, both in March as well as when we reported our first quarter or our fourth quarter and prior year results in January, we said at that time that we
componenttext: Well, let me address part of the question and ask Bob to address part of the question as well. If you recall, both in March as well as when we reported our first quarter or our fourth quarter and prior year results in January, we said at that time that we still believed that there's -- dependent upon the private equity firm, there affirms to have a very fundamental view that natural gas is a better place to invest than oil. They look at the activation costs of liquids and oil versus what they think is a fairly good market for natural gas at a good market for those folks, as I listen to them, as they feel very good about the ability of natural gas to run the $3 or more. From where we are today, they see that product, if you want to call it a quality product, just refer to is product, having better sustainability in the near term with less volatility than oil. So yes, you do have people who have fundamentally different views between the 2 hydrocarbons for think they want to invest in. And that's why we continue to see really good in balance when we take properties into the market and evaluate what the potential will be sold. As it relates to the comment about the balance sheet and the debt, I'm going to let Bob answer that one.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't generally discuss asset, particular assets, that we're looking at selling prior to, at least, getting into the market with them and then hopefully later in the stages, once we see what interest in those assets as and whether or not we might be in
componenttext: We don't generally discuss asset, particular assets, that we're looking at selling prior to, at least, getting into the market with them and then hopefully later in the stages, once we see what interest in those assets as and whether or not we might be interested in selling them. So I don't want to comment on the particular assets you mentioned that I don't think you should look for us to do something that you characterize as transformative. But we've got beyond the math that we've laid out there in terms of the closed and announced transactions and the $1.3 billion in the first quarter as of that March 1 Investor Call, and there's $700 million now. We put a range out there of $2 billion to $3 billion, so that leaves roughly another $1 billion that we're working on. And as we've said before, that's a risk number. So the gross number recognize a bigger number. there's some sizable assets in there and some small ones. And how that portfolio of assets held candidates come together is going to be based upon the relative demand for an interest in those assets from not just private equity but industry [indiscernible]. So as the year progresses, we will be greater clarity on that. And I think, the fact that we've laid out, I think, puts us in a position relative to what we believe is, even with a moderate recovery, still a relatively low commodity price environment, we believe, positions us for a pro forma appropriate leverage position.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, then a smaller one, just on obviously, great perks in the Delaware, the 5.2 million projected pad development from a 4,500 [ph] foot lateral. A couple of sort of comments around that. Longer-lateral testing, maybe if there's any color you can provid
componenttext: Okay, then a smaller one, just on obviously, great perks in the Delaware, the 5.2 million projected pad development from a 4,500 [ph] foot lateral. A couple of sort of comments around that. Longer-lateral testing, maybe if there's any color you can provide in terms of your efforts on the EUR side. And then on the cost side, can you lock in some of these lower costs because obviously, if you to get to work the cost me start to move back higher.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Darrell. We do core everything by the short lateral that is easier to do but there's no doubt that with our land position, we are doing some of the mids and longs. And they do give us better economics, if you will. The fact that we're down to
componenttext: Yes, this is Darrell. We do core everything by the short lateral that is easier to do but there's no doubt that with our land position, we are doing some of the mids and longs. And they do give us better economics, if you will. The fact that we're down to $6.2 million a well, I can tell you that's better than we thought we'd be doing at this point. And so it gives us pretty clear line of sight to the $5.2 million when we get to a pad drilling situation. So we feel really good about that. In terms of actually locking in those services, at this point, I have to say, we have actually recognized further benefits from not having that locked in. And so part of the savings, as Al mentioned earlier that we are recognizing still this year that may not be anticipated is what's going to allow us to continue to have a few more activities out in Delaware than we anticipated as well.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Ed, I will take your comment. You're right. As prices hopefully continue to make progress over the next the 1.5 years, it's likely, at some point, on the way, you'll see a service cost reaction. And I don't think you're wrong by saying at what point w
componenttext: But Ed, I will take your comment. You're right. As prices hopefully continue to make progress over the next the 1.5 years, it's likely, at some point, on the way, you'll see a service cost reaction. And I don't think you're wrong by saying at what point would you like to think about walking things in? And I think sustainability of higher prices for us is sort of a watchword. It's not without a whole lot of comment that volatility still concerns us. So consequently, we'll be a little cautious as we've looked at an improving price environment as well as trying to lock in costs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The one other comment I'd add is we've shown significant reductions, but it's not all associated with service costs, if you will. A lot of those reductions have to deal with just how fast we're able to drill these wells and some of the completions we're d
componenttext: The one other comment I'd add is we've shown significant reductions, but it's not all associated with service costs, if you will. A lot of those reductions have to deal with just how fast we're able to drill these wells and some of the completions we're doing now, lot of it has to do with efficiencies of activities and not completely with just reduced cost structure.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler of Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler of Simmons & Company.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And following up a little bit on the Delaware and DJ cost savings. In the Ops report, you highlighted the majority of that was being driven by completion cost savings. Can you give us a little bit more detail in terms of the drivers of that, whether it's
componenttext: And following up a little bit on the Delaware and DJ cost savings. In the Ops report, you highlighted the majority of that was being driven by completion cost savings. Can you give us a little bit more detail in terms of the drivers of that, whether it's substituting different products in there, whether it's purely efficiencies. Just increased detail would be very helpful.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, this is Darrell. It depends and where you're looking at. If you look at Delaware, probably have the cost savings, half of that million actually came from the drilling side and about 300 in the completion side of it, about 200 million on the f
componenttext: Well, again, this is Darrell. It depends and where you're looking at. If you look at Delaware, probably have the cost savings, half of that million actually came from the drilling side and about 300 in the completion side of it, about 200 million on the facility side. And so it's not all in the completions. We're seeing it in all facets. A lot of it is our cycled time. And in some cases, we're so getting like I said reduction in service costs, so that's contributing to it as a well. But to a large extent, it's really our times in all these areas as getting us there. And not so different in the DJ as well, where the reduction isn't quite as much. But if you look at the past few years, we've made a lot of strides there. And so the fact that we've gone from about 2.7 to 2.4 is not as big, but those incremental cycle time reductions is really what's getting us there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No doubt, very impressive. Switching over to the line of sight, the $700 million of divestitures in Q2. Can you talk a little bit about maybe what the EBITDA impact of that could be or any sort of operating cost impact of that and maybe anything with resp
componenttext: No doubt, very impressive. Switching over to the line of sight, the $700 million of divestitures in Q2. Can you talk a little bit about maybe what the EBITDA impact of that could be or any sort of operating cost impact of that and maybe anything with respect to geography targeted or hydrocarbons targeted?

componenttext: A very good try, Dave. But I'll tell you that the assets actually sold, we'll probably just keep mum about that. And then once they're closed, we come up to give you an update on guidance, we'll adjust both volumes as well as the cash impact from that.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about production mix in your key shale plays and how you expect that to evolve going forward? The Permian oil mix has increased and wondered if where you see that heading, particularly if you commit more down the road. If you commit more and
componenttext: Can you talk about production mix in your key shale plays and how you expect that to evolve going forward? The Permian oil mix has increased and wondered if where you see that heading, particularly if you commit more down the road. If you commit more and drill more there, do you expect a flattening and increase or decrease in the oil mix? And then also if you could comment on the Eagle Ford and the Wattenberg as well.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, generally speaking, as we've said before, quite a few quarters, we anticipate that our oil and liquids mix will be going up. Some of that is through the capital expenditures being focused today at completely and uniquely oil and liquids. Some of
componenttext: I think, generally speaking, as we've said before, quite a few quarters, we anticipate that our oil and liquids mix will be going up. Some of that is through the capital expenditures being focused today at completely and uniquely oil and liquids. Some of it also has to do with the gas divestitures that we've talked about, that we've realized on an certain assets that we anticipate sailing through the course of this year. So either through it organic or inorganic means, you can anticipate our oil and liquids will be a higher percentage of our overall mix. And I'll let Darrell, if I can, talk a little bit about what he's seeing in the particular basins you made reference to.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, as we talk about Delaware, we can't be real specific there because of our big acreage holding there. But as we continue to delineate across there, I think, in all cases, we're pretty excited. But as we've mentioned before, as you go east to west, a
componenttext: Brian, as we talk about Delaware, we can't be real specific there because of our big acreage holding there. But as we continue to delineate across there, I think, in all cases, we're pretty excited. But as we've mentioned before, as you go east to west, as we go west, our EURs are definitely picking up. But some of the GOR's, but the nice thing is you're still sitting at about 60% oil on the west side with a bigger GOR or with a bigger EURs. But even the east side of our field, we're about 70% oil, and we're really excited about that piece as well. So I think overtime, it will prove that it will increase our oil percentage as a whole in the U.S., particularly for onshore. But as it particularly to this asset, it's just hard to predict every year what we're doing just because of where we're drilling across all the acreage right now.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then the Wattenberg and Eagle Ford where we've seen the mix become a little bit less oily, is that just a function for structure and reduce drilling activity? Or is there something different more to that?
componenttext: Got it. And then the Wattenberg and Eagle Ford where we've seen the mix become a little bit less oily, is that just a function for structure and reduce drilling activity? Or is there something different more to that?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in Wattenberg, you can expect more the same. It's just a matter of when we pick up our activities again. But obviously, that's closer to 50% oil. And I think you'll see that hold true for the balance. And Eagle Ford, we don't actually have a
componenttext: Well, I think in Wattenberg, you can expect more the same. It's just a matter of when we pick up our activities again. But obviously, that's closer to 50% oil. And I think you'll see that hold true for the balance. And Eagle Ford, we don't actually have any activity levels playing in the near term, so I don't think you'll see that percentage changing as well. It's a little pretty much producing what we have right now until prices come up.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, this is Al. I know you know this. Our Eagle Ford production has a mix there compared to the same as you might see for some of the other companies you cover. Ours has always been a fairly lean oil and even with that, higher gravity oil wealth of
componenttext: And Brian, this is Al. I know you know this. Our Eagle Ford production has a mix there compared to the same as you might see for some of the other companies you cover. Ours has always been a fairly lean oil and even with that, higher gravity oil wealth of some of the folks to the north and east of it.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, that's great. And then I figured I'd throw this one in. Al, you were pretty vocal and clear on your last call regarding where issuing a pretty somewhat within your priorities low on the list. I wondered if you can just talk in the context of b
componenttext: Absolutely, that's great. And then I figured I'd throw this one in. Al, you were pretty vocal and clear on your last call regarding where issuing a pretty somewhat within your priorities low on the list. I wondered if you can just talk in the context of being in a better environment now versus 90 days ago both for our the person EPC share price whether your views have changed at all.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly don't see a need to issue an equity or any balance sheet restoration. So I mean, the comments that I've made and others of our management team have made, would to hold true even as we've gotten to a better environment both for the commo
componenttext: Well, we certainly don't see a need to issue an equity or any balance sheet restoration. So I mean, the comments that I've made and others of our management team have made, would to hold true even as we've gotten to a better environment both for the commodity outlook as well as where share prices have traded versus 90 days ago, those comments still hold.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-ups. Al, when you think about the service industry and kind of the -- if we get in a rebound scenario here, do you think anything changes as far as structure of service contract and what you guys are able to do as far as locking in
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-ups. Al, when you think about the service industry and kind of the -- if we get in a rebound scenario here, do you think anything changes as far as structure of service contract and what you guys are able to do as far as locking in post this in a recovery that scenario if anything changing there we expect the same old 2-year rate type of thing and locking it in?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we would certainly be willing to entertain thoughts that the service providers might have. Historically, they've not really wanted to go out for too long. And I think we, as industry, not just Anadarko have not really want to go out for too
componenttext: Well, I mean, we would certainly be willing to entertain thoughts that the service providers might have. Historically, they've not really wanted to go out for too long. And I think we, as industry, not just Anadarko have not really want to go out for too long. Whether we move from a spot basis to some contractual basis will be Darrell's call and his folks if we see that market evolving. But there, I don't think today here too motivated. Are you?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, as I mentioned earlier, again we're still see some benefits of reduced costs. I don't think now is the time. But we'll continue to look at it this year and into next year as to what may be best. But there's other things available to us in terms of whe
componenttext: No, as I mentioned earlier, again we're still see some benefits of reduced costs. I don't think now is the time. But we'll continue to look at it this year and into next year as to what may be best. But there's other things available to us in terms of whether we'd try to consolidate some of our efforts. And so we'll be -- we'll continue to be tough with some of the service sector to figure out what's the best way forward.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just Darrell, one follow-up. When you're talking about pad drilling and the ability to get down to about 5 2 [ph], how much does pad drilling save you on that kind of per-well, per-location type business, what's your best guess?
componenttext: Okay. And then just Darrell, one follow-up. When you're talking about pad drilling and the ability to get down to about 5 2 [ph], how much does pad drilling save you on that kind of per-well, per-location type business, what's your best guess?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I'm missing your point. I mean, it's $1 million from where we are today. Obviously, we're not in a pad drilling situation today. So our best guess right now is 6 2 [ph] to 5 2 [ph]. And so that'll be $1 million of copy. So I think that's very d
componenttext: I'm sorry, I'm missing your point. I mean, it's $1 million from where we are today. Obviously, we're not in a pad drilling situation today. So our best guess right now is 6 2 [ph] to 5 2 [ph]. And so that'll be $1 million of copy. So I think that's very doable for what we're seeing today and probably some pressure to bring that lower.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So all that $1 million savings is all on just to the pad drilling?
componenttext: Okay. So all that $1 million savings is all on just to the pad drilling?

componenttext: Yes, yes, that will be B, C and E.

componenttext: And our next question comes from John from Société Générale.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones for me. Supreme Court just negated local communities' ability to limit drilling activity. I know you work very well with the communities within Colorado and the DJ. But is this making your life a little bit easier with that Supreme Court de
componenttext: Two quick ones for me. Supreme Court just negated local communities' ability to limit drilling activity. I know you work very well with the communities within Colorado and the DJ. But is this making your life a little bit easier with that Supreme Court decision?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we were certainly happy that the Supreme Court in Colorado solved the issue correctly. So I think for now, yes would be the answer.
componenttext: Well, we were certainly happy that the Supreme Court in Colorado solved the issue correctly. So I think for now, yes would be the answer.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And regarding the Delaware, you just increased your resource size materially. Do you have enough infrastructure? Or should we plan to view in Western perhaps to have more buildout of the infrastructure so you can capture those resources?
componenttext: Okay. And regarding the Delaware, you just increased your resource size materially. Do you have enough infrastructure? Or should we plan to view in Western perhaps to have more buildout of the infrastructure so you can capture those resources?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we have done in the Delaware Basin, much like we did in the DJ Basin, we've tried to pace our midstream buildout with our upstream. If we get into the situation where we believe the Delaware Basin provides us attractive places to create rates of
componenttext: Well, as we have done in the Delaware Basin, much like we did in the DJ Basin, we've tried to pace our midstream buildout with our upstream. If we get into the situation where we believe the Delaware Basin provides us attractive places to create rates of return and good cash-on-cash characteristics, you can anticipate we'll pace our midstream spending to keep up with the upstream.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jim Sullivan of Alembic Global Advisers.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jim Sullivan of Alembic Global Advisers.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of the big strategies have been asked. That is want to nitty-gritty one and kind of a question from the Q here. Obviously, you guys had to post some collateral against the credit derivative liabilities in the quarter or more of that as a result of th
componenttext: Most of the big strategies have been asked. That is want to nitty-gritty one and kind of a question from the Q here. Obviously, you guys had to post some collateral against the credit derivative liabilities in the quarter or more of that as a result of the Moody's downgrading you talked about that. In my reading that you correctly that net of that collateral the remains $1.1 billion of net credit derivative liability. And is there is one of the first thing. The second is how do you guys assess the risk of having post any further collateral? Is there a triggering event that would do that, I mean, another downgrade or something that would be kind of unlikely or is it something that is positioned. Counterparties? Any color on that will be great.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We used about $600 million in cash to post collateral that was related to the Moody's downgrade. Most of that's related to individual with various banks and derivative counterparties. We also -- the one other effect that is kind of a collateral-orie
componenttext: Sure. We used about $600 million in cash to post collateral that was related to the Moody's downgrade. Most of that's related to individual with various banks and derivative counterparties. We also -- the one other effect that is kind of a collateral-oriented event related to the Moody's downgrades is various of our transportation agreements that have credit rating-related triggers. We've generally been able to satisfy those with LCs and a little bit of cash here and there yet. Obviously, there's still some room. There's room for improvement or additional cash postings as underlying value of the derivative moves around. Relative to your question of further downgrades, if we retain investment-grade ratings with the other rating indices, then there wouldn't be any subsequent triggers, certain if there are structure with the highest of your ratings and certain with the lower of your ratings. And so once with the lower of the ratings are the ones that resulted in a cash need during the quarter, which we funded. And probably, that cash is on the balance sheet, but in theory, it could certainly come back.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just high-level for a second. Can you guys comment on your view of the FA market? Generally, obviously, the Rockies assets have been deep interjection for a while. But there's been a lot of talk now about prospects for reduced transaction lat
componenttext: Okay, great. Just high-level for a second. Can you guys comment on your view of the FA market? Generally, obviously, the Rockies assets have been deep interjection for a while. But there's been a lot of talk now about prospects for reduced transaction late '16, '17 as enterprise. And some of the crackers come down. Do you guys have some general macro view on that, that you want to offer us?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Moore. I would say 2 things. First of all, the FA market is improving, with about $0.5 million demand coming on between exports and cracker additions, as you mentioned. You're seeing that in the FA upgrade relative to the residue pricing, th
componenttext: This is Scott Moore. I would say 2 things. First of all, the FA market is improving, with about $0.5 million demand coming on between exports and cracker additions, as you mentioned. You're seeing that in the FA upgrade relative to the residue pricing, the test premium. There's still some longer-term challenges with productive capacity relative to demand growth.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from David Aiken of Aiken and Energy.

componenttext: Thinking a lot bigger picture, Al and Bob, you all do a really good job measuring your company performance and rate of return driven. How would you think about the rate of return on roughly $900 million of capital invested in 1Q and kind of distribution from midstream return versus upstream return?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, David, I think when we look at a midstream return from an APC perspective, that might be different than a Western Gas. So if I could just stay with Anadarko only for a minute because typically, in the past at least, when we make an upstream investme
componenttext: Well, David, I think when we look at a midstream return from an APC perspective, that might be different than a Western Gas. So if I could just stay with Anadarko only for a minute because typically, in the past at least, when we make an upstream investment, we think about the cost of also getting that to whatever the delivery points, so that midstream buildout is a part of the upstream spend. So it would be a rate of return that would include getting the product into a market. Now that's different than Western Gas. I know you fully appreciate that. That's what going back to 2008, we sold those 2 markets valuing the assets different the. And while we put Western Gas in place as a result, we thought like it's really give us a lot of optionality around 2 distinct assets, although from the standpoint of the investment, if you can't move a hydrocarbon into a market, then you haven't completed the cost of completion. So when we look at whatever we're doing new or whatever Darrell maybe as an example is thinking about incrementally in the Delaware basin, that buildout, if it's on our nickel, will include that rate of return bundled will be the upstream. Now it's Western Gas evolves and as lifecycle and becomes larger, in many cases, particularly, say, for instance, in the Permian, we're Western Gas has a lot of stand-alone third-party business, then that becomes a little bit different equation. And maybe with that, if I could, I'll let Bob just approach it a little bit with Darrell by saying that you do have a bifurcation, where Western Gas has its own rates of return and has its own rates of return. But we do think about the process I mean gathering in a vacuum pretty much the way I just described it. And Bob, I don't know if you have any thing you would like to add.

And of course, West is very competitive in terms of its rates of return and their primarily cost of service agreements with Anadarko and third-party producers. Western's economics are self-evident in their own financials and the report earnings, I think, tomorrow.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. The number of well was between the discovery and the #3. And it came in exactly as we had prognosed, about 100 feet true vertical thickness. The advantage with the horizontal is that you got to see a lot of that section in a lateral sense, whi
componenttext: Yes, David. The number of well was between the discovery and the #3. And it came in exactly as we had prognosed, about 100 feet true vertical thickness. The advantage with the horizontal is that you got to see a lot of that section in a lateral sense, which confirmed our seismic interpretation. Our EEI volume would have said the exact same thing. And really, the deliverability issue around the #5 is to get as good of a rate as quick as we can do Sunday pressure most of the 1 and 3 so that we can improve connectivity. So we wanted as much reservoir section open to give us those high volumes and a good pressure drawdown pulse that would send -- that we can then monitor because that's a key question that we have to have answered before we move into a development phase is what is the connectivity other reservoir. So there were reasons beyond the actual ultimate production of this field that we put a horizontal well here because it's going to accelerate the evaluation the during the appraisal phase of and get us better data quicker. And so that's one of the main reasons that we did it in this case.

componenttextpreview: Okay, John. We'll tagteam you with those three questions. Let me start by saying having infrastructure in the Gulf of Mexico definitely separates us from many, but not all of our peers. It allows companies like ourselves to be able to look to commercializ
componenttext: Okay, John. We'll tagteam you with those three questions. Let me start by saying having infrastructure in the Gulf of Mexico definitely separates us from many, but not all of our peers. It allows companies like ourselves to be able to look to commercialize opportunities in this price environment at attractive rates of return that we wouldn't be able to even consider without the leverage of that infrastructure. Consequently, as we think about the infrastructure we have today, we're pretty comforted by the fact that it gives us that kind of optionality. And whether it's for our own volumes, as you described, or for the production handling agreement that we would have in place to move that for others, we see that as a real strategic advantage for us. And I might ask Jim to handle the second part of your question and ask Bob Danielson with the third part.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the question around the economics and the inventory, I think I'll address from what we have in our existing fields. And as Al stated, those tiebacks provide very good opportunities because they're generally high flow rate wells with very little connect
componenttext: So the question around the economics and the inventory, I think I'll address from what we have in our existing fields. And as Al stated, those tiebacks provide very good opportunities because they're generally high flow rate wells with very little connection costs to the existing subsea infrastructure. In a lot of cases where we have the infrastructure already installed and we have available processing capacity and pipeline takeout capacity, we can lever that infrastructure, which has already been depreciated, not only with our own equity opportunities, as we've mentioned, in Caesar-Tonga and some of our infield wells and Lucius, but also with other tieback that may be close proximity to our hubs. And so oftentimes, you'll find other operators, who have had discoveries, who may be not as large to justify a greenfield development but have tieback capability within distances, within negotiated process handling agreements. So those opportunities are out there. We continue to seek those as well as operators seek those tieback to us. Regarding the Miocene opportunity, after what we currently have identified all that -- I'll address that from an exploration standpoint. .

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, from an exploration standpoint, I don't see that the Miocene inventory is exhausted in the Gulf of Mexico. We just had a discovery last year at Yeti in Miocene for drilling several wells this year, both tiebacks and one, which is really an expl
componenttext: Yes, John, from an exploration standpoint, I don't see that the Miocene inventory is exhausted in the Gulf of Mexico. We just had a discovery last year at Yeti in Miocene for drilling several wells this year, both tiebacks and one, which is really an exploratory around our K2 area called Warrior, which is a very good Miocene prospect. We think we're the current high bidder on 2 prospects, 4 blocks and my the most recently just Miocene prospects. So we see still potential out there for not only tieback opportunities but for potential stand-alone exploratory wells. So we're continuing to work that.

componenttext: I'm not sure that, that's probably the best use of our balance sheet or our capital. So we would anticipate those rigs rolling off contract with the contracts are due. There may be some cases where we take a holiday with our rig, but we don't anticipate that in the schedule as you see it right now.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I'd like to remind you that today's presentation includes certain forward-looking statements and non-GAAP financial mea
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. 
I'd like to remind you that today's presentation includes certain forward-looking statements and non-GAAP financial measures and to let you know that a number of factors could cause results to differ materially from what we discuss today. So I encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and the GAAP reconciliations located on our website and attached to yesterday's earnings release. 
In just a moment, I'll turn the call over to Al Walker for some brief opening remarks, but first, I'd like to introduce Brian Cook, who has rejoined our Investor Relations team and will be available to assist you with questions, along with the rest of the team. I'll also remind you that we have additional detail on our quarterly ops report available on our website. And following Al's prepared remarks, we'll open up for questions with Al and the rest of the team. Al?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning. I think it almost goes without saying that things feel better today than it did 90 days ago, both for our industry and for investors. The very fragile energy capital markets we've seen for most of the first quarter appear t
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning. I think it almost goes without saying that things feel better today than it did 90 days ago, both for our industry and for investors. The very fragile energy capital markets we've seen for most of the first quarter appear to be stabilizing, the outlook for commodity prices are improving and I think for industry, our operating environment is definitely strengthening. As a company, our employees delivered very solid results despite the challenges in the first quarter. As a company, we're poised to take advantage of the market as opportunities develop. 
If I could, let me take a moment and recap what we achieved in the first quarter. We announced a capital plan that was 50% lower than 2015 and 70% lower than 2014. Our cap plan produces all volumes are expected to be flat year-over-year as well as on an exit rate basis. We monetized $1.3 billion of assets with another $700 million expected in the second quarter. We will continue to be an industry leader in active portfolio management. 
We reduced our dividend 81%, which we believe will save us $450 million of cash per annum, and we positioned our company to be more successful financially and operationally in the years ahead if prices stay lower. Our savings from these efforts, we believe, will increase our ability to be more cost-efficient and should provide more than $350 million of costs in savings per annum. We issued $3 billion of fixed income securities to refinance our 2016 debt and the first 125 -- well, pardon me, $1.25 billion of our 2017 debt at very attractive rates and terms. 
Operationally, we continue to set a very high bar. As you've seen, our reductions in various cost savings, LOE per barrel improved 22% in the first quarter versus the prior year. Our liquids mix continues to increase and our well costs in the DJ were reduced 11% from the year before to a level today of about $2.4 million per well. The Delaware Basin also has seen really good efforts as well with cost reductions where their wells are costing us $1 million per well less quarter-over-quarter to about $6.2 million per copy. 
What can you expect from us through the balance of the year? Do not expect us to increase our capital spending this year even if oil exceeds $50. We could reallocate some of our savings in our budget to increase capital to certain plays like the Delaware basin. We'll be very patient as we look beyond 2016 to a sustained higher price environment to increase capital and return to a growth mode, if warranted. Our operations report includes various highlights across our portfolio, and I encourage you to take a look at that for more details as your time permits.
Our employees have done an incredible job, as I mentioned earlier, during this first quarter, maintaining a focus on safety and productivity, meeting the challenges of a workforce reduction without losing focus on our operating results, being aggressive with portfolio management and diligent in our divestiture process. They've consistently and constantly look for ways to improve our business and manage through this volatile cycle successfully. 
Working to improve our financial position is something we think about every day, and I think the most recent example of that is the receipt of our cash tax refund approaching $1 billion through a lot of good efforts. Our combined efforts to improve our cash inflows will position us through the balance of the year to reduce our net debt. 
In closing, I think we've taken the right actions in the first quarter to position Anadarko for success. We do believe we're going to continue to see improving commodity prices, but however, near-term volatility remains a concern. Our industry and company are both in a much better place than we were 90 days ago, and it gives us renewed optimism this cycle is on a track to much better investment returns. 
With that, why don't we open it up for questions?

componenttext: Yes. This is Jim. The Heidelberg facility came online 3 months ahead of schedule. I just want to complement the project team for being able to achieve that goal. If you recall last year, there were a lot of interruptions in the Gulf of Mexico with loop currents and still managed to get that facility up and running ahead of schedule with just seamless hook up in commissioning schedule. We've got 3 wells currently producing. Those 3 wells are running about a combined 15,000 barrels a day. We have 2 wells that are on planned on the second half of this year and we're going to target those wells in sections of the reservoir that we think will have very good deliverability. And we should be looking towards production ramping up to 40,000-plus barrels a day towards the end of the year than 2017.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, your question on WGP. I don't know that I'd say it's back to the table. Our view is that it's a ready source of liquidity at a point in time. Certainly, it would be more attractive to us as something we would consider, given where it's trading now r
componenttext: Doug, your question on WGP. I don't know that I'd say it's back to the table. Our view is that it's a ready source of liquidity at a point in time. Certainly, it would be more attractive to us as something we would consider, given where it's trading now relative to the kind of unrealistic lows earlier in the space as the MLP sector took quite a hit. But frankly, we understand the go-forward plans around the MLPs because largely, Western Gas and WGP's fortunes are pretty closer related to our activities in the DJ and in the Delaware and to a number of other producers in the Delaware that are customers of Western Gas is there. So we're going to take a look at the value of that asset over time, just like we do with the rest of the assets in our monetization program. And if we think that relatively fair value can be achieved, then we'd consider. But we don't have any current plans to sell WGP. It's not one of the assets that we're currently working on or that our comments on the $700 million of pretty substantial progress over the last couple of months was related to.

componenttextpreview: No targets that we're setting out there. I think that if you look at the monetization target that we put in place and the guidance around the underlying numbers, you'd look to build cash. Clearly, during the second quarter, Al referenced the tax refund th
componenttext: No targets that we're setting out there. I think that if you look at the monetization target that we put in place and the guidance around the underlying numbers, you'd look to build cash. Clearly, during the second quarter, Al referenced the tax refund that we received. We'd be building cash during the second quarter and early on through the end of the year. Certainly, well north of $1 billion and whether or not it's north of 2 or more, largely tied to our decisions around asset sales. And as we said before, those -- obviously, the cash has the result of lower net debt and our expectation is that we would take a pretty significant portion of the cash that we build and apply it toward actual debt reduction including the last $750 million associated with our 2017 maturities. In an earlier press release, we pointed out that that $750 million would be repaid from cash on hand, and that cash would be generated through additional monetizations.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My operational follow-up is actually on Shenandoah. A couple of things, I guess, I'm interested in there. You obviously have a partner sell their interests, although not specific on Shenandoah exactly. It looks like it was a fairly low number. You g
componenttext: Okay. My operational follow-up is actually on Shenandoah. A couple of things, I guess, I'm interested in there. You obviously have a partner sell their interests, although not specific on Shenandoah exactly. It looks like it was a fairly low number. You guys have preempted rights. So I'm wondering what your thoughts are there, both when it comes to the value of your position, but also the fact that we're now 5 appraisal wells in. What are you seeing there that is taking so long to appraise it as you like? Is it really just scale, something unique to the reservoir that may make it a little bit more challenging to get a sanctioned decision? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, understandable questions. I think the first part of the question, I'll address and ask Bob Daniels to talk to you more specifically about what you're seeing from the appraisal perspective. The press period is running. I think you should expect that
componenttext: Doug, understandable questions. I think the first part of the question, I'll address and ask Bob Daniels to talk to you more specifically about what you're seeing from the appraisal perspective. The press period is running. I think you should expect that we will, hopefully, be communicating something towards the end of that press period. And I think your observations, I can't find any fault with them.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Doug, on the wells and the appraisal program, it's partly scale, it's partly -- some of the complexities that we're seeing out there, mostly on the imaging side of it, not necessarily that we're seeing lots of bad surprises. Although we did, through
componenttext: Yes. Doug, on the wells and the appraisal program, it's partly scale, it's partly -- some of the complexities that we're seeing out there, mostly on the imaging side of it, not necessarily that we're seeing lots of bad surprises. Although we did, through our most recent wells, realize that there are some faults that we're poorly to not imaged and some of the seismic data that we're going to have to build into a potential development plan. And so that means that we needed a few more appraisal wells to make sure that there's not any more compartmentalization as we move across. So those are the issues that we're looking at. I'd say it's mostly based around the quality of the image in the sub-salt and making sure that what we're seeing or interpreting is actual reality, and so we're drilling the 5 well now to the West and pushing that downdip quite significantly to prove up of those volumes as we move over. And then with success there, we'd move over even farther to the -- I'm sorry, to the East, and we'd move over even farther to the East with the #6 well. So those are what's happening there. The biggest issue on timing and making sure that we have the data is -- this can be a big development if we move forward with it. And it's going to be an expensive development and you want to know what the well deliverabilities are going to be, what your actual resources range are going to and you want to come up with a solution that actually makes sense for this resource. And it's in a technically challenging environment from a pressure standpoint. We have to make sure we get it right before we take those final decisions. So that's kind of what we're working on right now.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate your answer, Bob. Al, if I may, just a quick follow-up for you on this. ConocoPhillips is  also -- is publicly selling its deepwater position. I'm just curious, could you [indiscernible] position where your working interest gets to a scale in Shenandoah, basically, do another capital efficient farm done? Or is that unlikely at this point?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't had direct conversations with Conoco on that topic. I think your observation is sort of what is our playbook is a fair one. I think as we continued to understand the things that Bob just made reference to better than we do today, we would
componenttext: Well, we haven't had direct conversations with Conoco on that topic. I think your observation is sort of what is our playbook is a fair one. I think as we continued to understand the things that Bob just made reference to better than we do today, we would certainly consider options in the future. But I think, at this juncture, to assume that we would be interested in increasing our working interest position at the size that, for instance, ConocoPhillips is at, without additional information, probably in the category of not likely.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had one question on just the U.S. oil production guidance. Despite some of the concerns in Heidelberg, you guys did reiterate your U.S. oil production outlook for the full year, but you did guide to lower volumes in Q2. Can you just go through why U.S.
componenttext: I had one question on just the U.S. oil production guidance. Despite some of the concerns in Heidelberg, you guys did reiterate your U.S. oil production outlook for the full year, but you did guide to lower volumes in Q2. Can you just go through why U.S. oil volumes will be down a little bit in Q2?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start, if I could, around with the comment that Heidelberg is actually performing relative to the guidance that we gave to investors through the course of the year. So we may be different from you, don't see Heidelberg performing any differen
componenttext: Well, let me start, if I could, around with the comment that Heidelberg is actually performing relative to the guidance that we gave to investors through the course of the year. So we may be different from you, don't see Heidelberg performing any differently than we anticipated this year. As the wells that we expect to drill and have produced to date, they performed as we anticipated. So the comments and the concerns associated with Heidelberg leave me a little bit in the category of scratching my head. Now as it relates to oil volumes through the course of the year, as I'm sure you can appreciate in a capital-intensive business, onshore, we have certain places where we're adding to capital and certain places we're taking away. But I think we have given you largely the types of volumes we anticipate through the year. The one thing that we can't anticipate and schedule well is liftings. And liftings sometimes happen either to our advantage or disadvantage. But I think the thing that we still feel like, and I made this in my earlier comments, is that we believe, for the year, we will be flat year-over-year on all volumes and probably, just as importantly, on an exit rate basis, so no change from our perspective on that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up, Al, is just looking at Mozambique, there are some press reports that big oil is looking at taking a stake in ENI's Area 4. I was just wondering if you could talk about some of the implications if you saw someone lik
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up, Al, is just looking at Mozambique, there are some press reports that big oil is looking at taking a stake in ENI's Area 4. I was just wondering if you could talk about some of the implications if you saw someone like Exxon in Area 4, do you view that as positive, negative or neutral in terms of Anadarko's ability to develop your discoveries in Mozambique?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me answer you this way. And I guess until we have a new partner in the unitization process of Prosperidade in Mamba with Areas 1 and 4, we work very hard every day with the partners that we know about. And to extent that changes, then I'll make
componenttext: Well, let me answer you this way. And I guess until we have a new partner in the unitization process of Prosperidade in Mamba with Areas 1 and 4, we work very hard every day with the partners that we know about. And to extent that changes, then I'll make a comment at that time.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounds very simply as this your first aim is to pay down some debt and then at a given price you'll resume growth spending focusing on the U.S. Within that overall basic outline, I was wondering your previous success as deepwater explorers feels like i
componenttext: It sounds very simply as this your first aim is to pay down some debt and then at a given price you'll resume growth spending focusing on the U.S. Within that overall basic outline, I was wondering your previous success as deepwater explorers feels like it's somewhat on hold now. Can you talk about where deepwater exploration and I guess, what separates it between the GOM and international? When will that come back? Is it at a price? Is it sometime in the future? I'm struggling to understand where that fits in the kind of new world oil.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Understandable question, Paul. Thank you for asking it. I think, as we've talked about this year, we see a number of tieback opportunities in the Gulf of Mexico that have very attractive potential rates of return if they're drilled out successfully.
componenttext: Yes. Understandable question, Paul. Thank you for asking it. I think, as we've talked about this year, we see a number of tieback opportunities in the Gulf of Mexico that have very attractive potential rates of return if they're drilled out successfully. You may see those categorized as exploration or exploitation. Certainly, the existence of infrastructure allows us to go out and drill something today that is an exploration well, with the ability to tie it back to existing infrastructure and reduce the development costs. I think the area that you're focused on, and accurately so, is if we're looking at true new infrastructure to support exploration efforts, are we likely to do that in an environment where we're drilling below salt? And I think, today, as we made the comment on the last call, that's pretty challenging a bit of arithmetic. So I think we'll continue to look for opportunities in the near term, for which we've given some good detail in our ops report and other color commentary around it, that we think in the Gulf of Mexico, we have really good opportunities to tie back to infrastructure to take advantage of our exploitation, exploration and development that we see there. Outside the U.S., we look at places where, basically, in a post-salt environment where the well costs are substantially less, as I know you fully appreciate. And there, as we have before, we see exploration creating option value for the future. That turned out to be a pretty good premise for which we think that our business strategy, and I know you know it quite well, but when we think about short-term, medium-term and long-term cycling of cash, cycling of cash for us in the short term has produced extremely good rates of return and good characteristics of cash-on-cash. The medium- and long-term cycling is more to create that option value and enhance value for the future. Whether we take that to production and development will be dependent upon the price environment at that time. So I'm not -- I mean, I'm not probably inching your question as specifically as you answered it, but I am trying to approach it from the standpoint it still fits in the business model, which I think we've done a pretty good job of since 2007 of staying within. And that's just simply thinking about the cycling of cash, the rates of return for the near term, thinking about the value added from the long term, from an option standpoint, staying within cash inflows with our investing and being mindful of early aggressive portfolio management in order to enhance these rates of return of the value creation. And -- well, maybe if I could go have Bob Daniels talk a little bit about what we're seeing specifically in other areas with our exploration beyond just the quantitative assessment I gave you.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Paul, I'd say that we're not on hold. We've slowed down like we've done in all sectors of our business given the cash flows that we have now in the capital program. But this year, we're in Côte d’Ivoire drilling appraisal wells and then we're goin
componenttext: Yes. Paul, I'd say that we're not on hold. We've slowed down like we've done in all sectors of our business given the cash flows that we have now in the capital program. But this year, we're in Côte d’Ivoire drilling appraisal wells and then we're going to do a DST at our Paon complex. And then follow that up with 2 exploratory wells to the South and exploration acreage we have adjacent to that. So that's all are going to be very interesting. The rig from there, we'll move back into Colombia and do an appraisal well on our Kronos discovery and follow that up, hopefully, next year, with some additional work down in the Fuerte area. Meanwhile, we're acquiring a huge -- the second half of a huge 3D up in Col area and the deepwater Colombia. We really are excited with what we're seeing on the first phase and looking forward to get that second phase done and putting that whole program together. And then meanwhile in the Gulf, Al mentioned the -- all the tiebacks and all the -- near infrastructure work that we're doing this year. And that is similar to what we're doing at Phobos where we have discovery in the lower tertiary that we're going to try to get on appraisal later in the year. So we've got quite a few things that are going on. And when you look out to the future, 16 million acres in the deepwater of Colombia, we picked up our current high bidder for new blocks in the Gulf of Mexico. So we're continuing to move forward, but it's got to be within the context of the price environment that we find ourselves. And we're trying to set ourselves up for the future as we come out of this. So that's where we're focused on and we still got a very good program going.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand that. And I guess, successful exploration is value adding at almost any oil price and so it becomes a question of risking the exploration. I think what you just said to me is that there's an issue first in thinking about risk between pre- and
componenttext: I understand that. And I guess, successful exploration is value adding at almost any oil price and so it becomes a question of risking the exploration. I think what you just said to me is that there's an issue first in thinking about risk between pre- and post-salt, and that would become a bit of a geographic question. To be specific, at Heidelberg, we've -- in the past, you've seen issues with the reservoirs in the Gulf of Mexico, deepwater Gulf of Mexico, is there a problem there and does that change your risk assumptions, especially given, I guess, we've also got the issue of government risk and the attraction of the U.S. against international and anything else you could help -- add to help me think about that would be very useful.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Jim, and I'll answer the question specifically regarding Heidelberg. We know this area of the Gulf of Mexico very well. It's Miocene section that is on the same trend as our Caesar/Tonga field and then on the Tahiti field. And with regard to
componenttext: Yes. This is Jim, and I'll answer the question specifically regarding Heidelberg. We know this area of the Gulf of Mexico very well. It's Miocene section that is on the same trend as our Caesar/Tonga field and then on the Tahiti field. And with regard to those reservoir rocks, the quality of them are very, very well. And I think what distinguishes Heidelberg is it's, structurally, is a little more complex because of the steepness of dipping beds up against the salt well. But we anticipate, just like Caesar/Tonga, which we bought online in Phase 1 was -- is in the process of being completed. These wells have very good flow characteristics with good porosity and permeability. So we anticipate good performance of our additional wells at Heidelberg. As an example, and part answer to the prior question, we initiated Phase 2 of Caesar/Tonga last year. And so we see additional extension of that field once we've resolved some of the reservoir well targeting locations and then the flow performance issues. So anticipate, just as we did in Caesar/Tonga, along the same trend, we'll do the same thing at Heidelberg.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, just to answer the question about the Gulf versus international and those types of things. We look at all of those types of things on the risk reward basis. And I think what Al was getting at is, the Gulf of Mexico pre-salt tends to be very expe
componenttext: And Paul, just to answer the question about the Gulf versus international and those types of things. We look at all of those types of things on the risk reward basis. And I think what Al was getting at is, the Gulf of Mexico pre-salt tends to be very expensive, they're deep, they're complex wells and so when you start looking at the reward for new developments out there, they've got a lot of capital that you got to put to work. And we see other places in the world that perhaps we can find that those similar type of resources that maybe are not quite as expensive to development. And in this price environment, we're paying attention to that very closely.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Charles Meade of Johnson Rice.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could go back to one of the themes you brought up in your prepared comments when you're talking about the environment for both Anadarko and the industry being a little more comfortable now than it was 3 months ago. And my question is does th
componenttext: I wonder if I could go back to one of the themes you brought up in your prepared comments when you're talking about the environment for both Anadarko and the industry being a little more comfortable now than it was 3 months ago. And my question is does that also extend to the buyers that you're seeing in that A&D market? I know you guys are looking to sell a lot of things and I'm curious if people have more appetite there. And if you could, if there's any differentiation you see between maybe operating companies or PE-backed companies or some of the traditional financial buyers that you've sold down to in the past?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I think both Bob and I have mentioned either in our earnings calls about 90 days ago or analyst call in March that we continue to see a pretty strong interest from people looking to buy properties from Anadarko. And I think the broader property m
componenttext: Charles, I think both Bob and I have mentioned either in our earnings calls about 90 days ago or analyst call in March that we continue to see a pretty strong interest from people looking to buy properties from Anadarko. And I think the broader property market certainly has a pretty good depth of private equity chasing it. But I think the other thing, and I continue to highlight this, is that when we look to monetize an asset, many times, we are a seller of choice from the standpoint that they're not taking on operational problems that you might be taking on with less capitalized companies or companies that don't have the operational history and success that we've had. So I think the fact that we've been a good, prudent operator for a long time, we're a brand name if you want to call it that in our space, when we choose to redeploy capital by exiting a particular property, you're not taking on problems that you might with a smaller or less well-known company. And that, to date, has endured to our benefit as you've seen a very successful effort in the last 2 years to monetize properties into, I think, anyone would describe as a very difficult environment. Now Bob Gwin deals with this day in and day out, and I would really like for him to please add to those comments.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, the only thing I'd add is that the economics you asked about is, Al's comment on the improving environment is that we've seen that read through. I think, in particular, yes, on the gas side. We've -- we had a number, we've mentioned that a number
componenttext: Charles, the only thing I'd add is that the economics you asked about is, Al's comment on the improving environment is that we've seen that read through. I think, in particular, yes, on the gas side. We've -- we had a number, we've mentioned that a number of the assets that we're focused on, considering the sale of today are gassy. And with the improvement in the forward curve, we've seen some strengthening in the interests for those assets. And it doesn't take a whole lot of improvement on the price side to get some materially better economics at the outside level. And so as you would expect, you see that read through in terms of the level of interest and in terms of the bids that we received. And obviously, on all these assets, we're reevaluating the sell case versus the hold case. And so the math gets better for us and then the questions what's the value in the item holder and how aggressively might they put capital on rigs to work on assets that are going to struggle to be allocated capital against our other very strong primarily oilier opportunities.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then if I could ask a question about the horizontal wells or maybe the concept of the horizontal wells offshore that you mentioned, offshore Côte d’Ivoire. Is that the kind of thing that we might be -- we might see in the fu
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then if I could ask a question about the horizontal wells or maybe the concept of the horizontal wells offshore that you mentioned, offshore Côte d’Ivoire. Is that the kind of thing that we might be -- we might see in the future in your Gulf of Mexico tiebacks? Or is this more the kind of thing that's applicable to these unconstrained stratigraphic plays that you're chasing and the rest of world?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Charles, I'll address it. There's going to be applications for it around the world. I don't think that's going to be like in the onshore U.S. where it becomes the prevailing methodology of drilling these wells. But in the case of the Paon wells and t
componenttext: Yes. Charles, I'll address it. There's going to be applications for it around the world. I don't think that's going to be like in the onshore U.S. where it becomes the prevailing methodology of drilling these wells. But in the case of the Paon wells and the development of that field or the appraisal of that field, we have very, very good imaging of the reservoir section using some in-house techniques that have allowed us to, ahead of the wells, essentially predict within a plus minus 10% accuracy, the gross sand count and so we were able to really place the well very, very accurately. And what it allows us to do then is also more reservoir section for DST that will give us data earlier on deliverability, conductivity, those types of things. So there was an application here that sped up the evaluation process. But the only reason we could do it is because we knew very, very accurately what to expect in the wellbore and how to place the lateral section, so it worked very well. We're doing the reentry of the #3. We'll also have a high-angle sidetrack out of it to monitor the DST results, but it will have applications better. It's not going to the tremendously widespread.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Al, I hate the kind of badger you on this, but with Heidelberg, certainly, there had been some obvious concern with what that's producing. And can you just talk in generalities what might be the differentiation between how you all looked in -- looked at t
componenttext: Al, I hate the kind of badger you on this, but with Heidelberg, certainly, there had been some obvious concern with what that's producing. And can you just talk in generalities what might be the differentiation between how you all looked in -- looked at that coming into the year versus your partner?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's twofold. I can't speak to what our partner provided in the way of guidance for the year, but I'll reiterate what I said earlier and that is, Heidelberg has produced exactly the way we've provided guidance to The Street. It's not underpe
componenttext: Well, I think it's twofold. I can't speak to what our partner provided in the way of guidance for the year, but I'll reiterate what I said earlier and that is, Heidelberg has produced exactly the way we've provided guidance to The Street. It's not underperformed and it's performed in line with what we thought the wells would do. So therefore, it doesn't seem to create, for us, the problems it seems to be creating for others. It maybe haven't taken as much time to look at it as we'd like them to. I think the other thing is you have to realize is that we have a very limited cost basis in this development. If you recall, a few years ago, we farmed down our interest there and almost all of our development cost has been borne by a third-party. In fact, there's still carry left associated with that farm-down. So therefore, if you're thinking about impairments, if you're thinking about balance sheet treatment, this asset would be carried on our books very differently than maybe some of our partners. So if people would take those 2 together, they might understand that we're not as concerned about Heidelberg as certainly it appears to be. Some people are as it might relate to our partner, but from our perspective, Heidelberg has produced in line with what we anticipated it would do for the year and relative to the way in which we provide guidance in The Street.

componenttext: Well, as we look at the estimated ultimate recovery with -- as we put new wells on and we see performance, then we'll continue to update our model in terms of what we think the ultimate recovery will be from Heidelberg. And as we see those wells come on and have some performance, we'll have additional commentary in quarters to come.

Because I think M3 pricing has improved and you all have the exposure to that.
