Good morning, and welcome to the Anadarko Petroleum's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to John. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter 2016 conference calls.I would like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financia
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter 2016 conference calls.
I would like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financial measures, and be aware that a number of factors would cause results to differ materially from what we discuss today. So I encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and the GAAP reconciliation located on our website and attached to yesterday's earnings release.
In just a moment, I'll turn the call over to Al Walker for some brief opening remarks, but first, I would like to thank Jeremy Smith for his contributions he's made to the IR group over the last couple of years. Jeremy is now on his new role as Vice President of Mozambique project finance.
And along with that, I'd like to introduce Pete, who has joined IR and who will be available to assist with questions later this afternoon, along with the rest of our team. 
I'll also remind you that we have a lot of additional detail in our quarterly ops report available on our website. And following Al's prepared remarks, we'll open up for questions with our executive team. Al?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning. As we turn the corner into the second half of 2016, we've made exceptional progress on the goals we established for this year of enhancing value, strengthening the balanced sheet, hydrating the portfolio and reducing cost.
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning. As we turn the corner into the second half of 2016, we've made exceptional progress on the goals we established for this year of enhancing value, strengthening the balanced sheet, hydrating the portfolio and reducing cost. 
In terms of enhancing value, our operating organization has done a tremendous job achieving several milestones during the quarter. As you can see on our operations report available online, we had outstanding performance in the Gulf of Mexico. This is an area where we had several competitive advantages, a successful exploration track record, an industry-leading project management capability and a large operated infrastructure position. 
Our Gulf assets provide us a capital efficient value driver, and our record production achievement at constitution and K2 are great examples of that. Our operating solutions facility also achieved record production during the quarter with oil volumes exceeding nameplate capacity. As I suspect you know that our ops report, we drove another appraisal well at Shenandoah. The Shenandoah 5 well encountered more than 1,000 feet of net oil play and expanded the eastern extent of the field with planning of the Shen 6 now underway. 
We have a 33% working interest in Shenandoah after participating in a right process, and through that process, we picked up some additional blocks and exploration opportunities at no cost. 
Record production levels are also achieved in the DJ and the Delaware basins, and we're able to increase our activity over initial expectations, while still keeping capital expenditures within guidance. 
In the Delaware Basin, we have further reduced our DC cost per well and improved our drilling cycle times, while advancing our delineation program across a very large acreage position. 
In the DJ Basin, we achieved record production while lowering our LOE by about 15% year-over-year. Our outstanding operating results are complemented by another year of strong monetization results. In the first quarter, we announced approximately 1.3 billion of monetizations. Since then, we've achieved and have received an additional 1.2 billion of proceeds and executed a successful secondary offering of WGP earnings. 
We now expect total proceeds to be at or above 3.5 billion for the full year. So far this year, through the cost structuring improvements I have mentioned as well as the dividend reduction and monetization efforts, we have significantly strengthened the balance sheet. 
We've done this by retiring 3 billion of near term maturities with our first quarter '16 common issuance and planning to retire the remaining 750 million of 2017 maturities from our monetization proceeds. 
The cautious approach we outlined for oil price recovery at the beginning of 2015 has played out as much as we anticipated. It now appears U.S. also flat peaked at around 9.6 million barrels per day, and we expect it to bottom out around 8 million barrels per day, all the while with global demand now exceeding expectations. 
Given this dynamic, I am now encouraged that a sustained $60 oil price environment is likely to emerge as we move into 2017. This price level should provide the necessary cash margins and resulting cash cycle improvements to encourage us to accelerate activity and achieve strong returns.
In this scenario, we would evaluate redeploying some of the incremental proceeds from asset sales towards our highest quality U.S. onshore assets later this year. 
Our unique position in the DJ and Delaware basins, combined with the tieback opportunities in the Gulf of Mexico, give us strong line of sight for attractive, capital efficient, short cycle oil investments as crude prices recover. 
With that, we would love to take your questions, and thanks for joining us this morning.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could this is on that. I think, one, that's going to be very depended upon what we'd anticipate to be a recovery in oil prices, but we're going to watch that pretty closely before we commit beyond the comments we're giving you this morning. But I'm -
componenttext: If I could this is on that. I think, one, that's going to be very depended upon what we'd anticipate to be a recovery in oil prices, but we're going to watch that pretty closely before we commit beyond the comments we're giving you this morning. But I'm -- for the first time since January of 2015, I think we see a window to a better oil prices. And I foreshadow this a little bit at the Wells Conference a few months ago when I made the comments there that we anticipate we'd have a leg down as the market tried to absorb the 3 million barrels associated with disruptions from Venezuela, Nigeria and Canada. And as the market went through that congestion, we've -- we're going to see the lag down that we're seeing right now. And I think once we get that behind us, to use an economics terms, there pair of us, we think we're looking at sustained $60 oil price environment for next year. But I think to the question you're asking and do we see greater evidence that our thoughts are in fact, true, will be a little slower and probably more likely to be willing to communicate that with greater clarity next quarter.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, we were pleased to what we saw in the #5 well. I'm not surprised, but we were very pleased to see it commence with predicted with 1,040-plus feet of peg [ph] . We're about a half-mile east of the #2 well, and then we're going to move farther ea
componenttext: Yes, Evan, we were pleased to what we saw in the #5 well. I'm not surprised, but we were very pleased to see it commence with predicted with 1,040-plus feet of peg [ph] . We're about a half-mile east of the #2 well, and then we're going to move farther east and down deep with the #6. With your question of what else is going to take, we're really have to see what the #6 tells us. If the #6 comes in as we project with the overwater contacts, we'll probably need to then sidetrack out of that. Try to go up dip, get in a full oil column in that. So the ultimate planning has to be after #6. We've got a lot of work that's going on right now though related to how we might develop this field. But again, we're still in the appraisal mode, and so we need to get the rest of the information in front of us.

I'd point to mad dog, which I believe VP spoke discussed the fact they're going to take a decision on this year, and they've indicated that sanction is likely. And I think there's just a couple of takeaways from that's not necessarily related to Shenandoah. One is they reduced the production solution cost from $20 billion to $8 billion, so that helps with the economics. And two, they think they've got an estimate also in recovery. That's pretty significant. And so the EUR combined with a lower cost probably gives you a threshold for price that would not have been anticipated a few years ago for sanctioning. So we're hopeful that some of those ingredients will work into our favor as that decisions comes to us over the last couple of years.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Leggate of Bank of America.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Al, one of the things, I guess, that makes guidance a little challenging, at least in terms of the production outlook, is the tieback schedule that you've obviously been quite successful in the Gulf of Mexico. I'm just wondering if you could give us some help on relative capital allocation? And I guess the way I would ask the question is what on key 2 [ph] on consolation in particular, what is the outreach that you could seek to fill? And what -- how does it relative priority of tieback stock of relative to capital on shore? I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you go back to our March presentation, the allocation that we laid out at that time gives you a pretty clear understanding I think. The only thing I would say that we would change from that is that simply if we find ourselves in an improv
componenttext: Well, I think if you go back to our March presentation, the allocation that we laid out at that time gives you a pretty clear understanding I think. The only thing I would say that we would change from that is that simply if we find ourselves in an improving oil price environment, which I said earlier I think is very likely, we would deploy that initially for the debt retirement for the maturities in 2017 and then we'll look to the 2 principle onshore assets in the DJ and the Delaware basin for that capital. That aside, Doug, I can't see any additional percentage allocation going differently than what we laid out in March, and it's too early to say at this juncture what we'll do for 2017.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I want a second follow-up, if I may, on the Delaware Basin. I know there's been a lot of charter about further on and if you could ever see an opportunity to acquire your partner's interest there. But, if I may, I want to try and ask that question a
componenttext: Okay. I want a second follow-up, if I may, on the Delaware Basin. I know there's been a lot of charter about further on and if you could ever see an opportunity to acquire your partner's interest there. But, if I may, I want to try and ask that question a little differently. Can you give us some color as to what the operated and nonoperated activity looks like? And what I'm really getting at is for how many wells are being proposed by Anadarko versus Shell? And what kind of participation you're getting from your partner? Because my understanding is that you may end up with high working interest in some of those incremental wells.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to let Darrell fill in some of the details, but that's a question that's really hard to answer because every package of that they send to us and we send to them causes that sort of change the landscape a little bit. We don't have great ins
componenttext: Well, I'm going to let Darrell fill in some of the details, but that's a question that's really hard to answer because every package of that they send to us and we send to them causes that sort of change the landscape a little bit. We don't have great insight into what sort of plans they have for developing those wells if they want to push AFEs towards us on. And ours, in terms of what we're planning to, I think by evidence and the fact that we're standing up a few more rigs speaks to our confidence in the field as well as gives you some insight that we think the oil prices are going to do. I think beyond that, I'm going to let Darrell fill you in just a little bit more on the details. But philosophically, Doug, I don't think it's likely that our partner there is a seller as best we can tell it. It doesn't seem like they're motivated to do so. And frankly, given the quality of the asset, I can understand that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, probably the follow- on with that. From a working interest standpoint, I think assuming a 50-50 is about where we're going to end up. And really are today, I don't see that really changing because of the addition of drilling that's going on. I can't
componenttext: Yes, probably the follow- on with that. From a working interest standpoint, I think assuming a 50-50 is about where we're going to end up. I can't speak to the future and the balance of the year, but I can tell you that as of today, we've got 6 rigs stood up and Shell has 2 rigs stood up.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about your view on the marketplace. And specifically, you guys have been very successful selling assets, but at some point, there was also talk of perhaps buying in the Delaware Basin. So could you talk about what you're seeing on the asse
componenttext: I wanted to ask about your view on the marketplace. And specifically, you guys have been very successful selling assets, but at some point, there was also talk of perhaps buying in the Delaware Basin. So could you talk about what you're seeing on the asset sale side? And what implications that might have for your ability to add in the Delaware basin?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think Bob Quinn is probably in the better position to answer that for you. And I'll just say before I pass to him, I think he and later in the folks that have been working that for us over the last several years, particularly in the last 24 months
componenttext: Sure. I think Bob Quinn is probably in the better position to answer that for you. And I'll just say before I pass to him, I think he and later in the folks that have been working that for us over the last several years, particularly in the last 24 months when market conditions have been pretty challenging have done an exceptional job. And we often talk about it being a core strength of ours in how we manage our portfolio. And well, I think we can do it even in times of challenging and stressful pricing. I noticed been a lot of investor concern that can you continue to sell assets in a very depressed market? And I couldn't be happier with what I think Bob and Gerry have done in the last couple of years. So, Bob, let me turn it over to you so you can answer the questions specifically.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. Charles, it's really a market today where we are buying and selling, but in a lot of small transaction. So it's things that are small enough that generally don't get reported. The ones that we're summarizing our asset divesture program were
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. Charles, it's really a market today where we are buying and selling, but in a lot of small transaction. So it's things that are small enough that generally don't get reported. The ones that we're summarizing our asset divesture program were generally our larger transactions. Or in some cases like in recently in the Permian where we saw some acreage that we had in the portfolio, felt like we wouldn't get to that acreage for quite a while and it didn't necessarily fit as well, relative to our development plans. And so we saw it is a unique opportunity to sell something. I think it's fair to say that the market should continue to be receptive based on the dynamics we're seeing. It should continue to be receptive for the types of assets that we're bringing to market. Those assets share a common characteristic that they're generally not going to attract capital in our portfolio. Really, virtually any gas price. And I mentioned the gas price because they're mostly dry gas assets. We will retain a lot of exposure to gas through the associated gas of our 2 primary U.S. onshore assets. But the dry gas assets have pretty good economics, intrinsic economics. It's strip pricing, and so we've seen buyers that see it as a neat assets, relative to the size of their firm and the types of things they're trying to do. Not as attractive to us and makes a lot of sense for us to sell. On the margin, we, however, are a buyer of assets. If they are priced right and if they're in the right location, really, the 3 core areas where we're putting capital and we believe we have competitive advantages in the Delaware, and in Wattenberg, and in the Gulf of Mexico or places where we continue to look at packages. We look at packages elsewhere, but in many cases, we don't see what our competitive advantage will be and what the synergy as to our existing operations. And so we have not been successful bidders on those packages where we've chosen to submit a bid.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful detail. And then picking up perhaps on the thread of the Wattenberg DJ Basin, I want to say maybe 1.5 years or 2 years ago that you started the call talking about the enigma or the puzzle of what was going on with the California -- or actua
componenttext: That's helpful detail. And then picking up perhaps on the thread of the Wattenberg DJ Basin, I want to say maybe 1.5 years or 2 years ago that you started the call talking about the enigma or the puzzle of what was going on with the California -- or actually, the Colorado initiatives. And it's a little different story this time around, but it feels like déjà vu for a lot of people. And the question is something in my mind is are we going to be stuck in this kind of loop in Colorado? So can you offer your thoughts on that front, on the political process environment in Colorado and perhaps if that interacts with your decision or your future decisions to accelerate in the DJ?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me take a comment or 2 on that.   One is we take what we do in the DJ Basin and Colorado broadly defined very seriously, and we try very hard everyday to be a part of educating the electric in the State. We feel like with knowledge of and unders
componenttext: Okay. Let me take a comment or 2 on that.   One is we take what we do in the DJ Basin and Colorado broadly defined very seriously, and we try very hard everyday to be a part of educating the electric in the State. We feel like with knowledge of and understanding and appreciation for what the industry does and how we're doing it and the issues associated with what setbacks really  mean to an educated folder is more likely to understand why this is important and why do valid initiative has structured, particularly this year, would do so much damage to the state. We think that's very important. We see both the U.S. cylinders from the state as well as the governor being very understanding of this issue. In fact, the Governor Hagan Luper was on CNBC earlier this morning, and I think he's considered one of the better governors in the United States. And certainly, he's very thoughtful around these issues being a part of the oil and gas industry much earlier in his career as a geologist. So I say politically, we have a very good understanding from both a Democratic governor, a Democratic senator and a Republican senator. And I think the politics in the state are such that we just need to continue to do what we can do with the help of other industry participants to educate the voters in a way when they do go the ballot and if the ballot were, in fact, on the docket for this fall, that they understand why they're voting on. And we take that very seriously every day as well as a lot of companies. Adding to that end, that's the best way I can address your question.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Crédit Suisse.

componenttext: I'm intrigued by the schematic that you put in the Delaware this office report, I mean, 24, 28. Well, across, obviously, the 3 to 4 different zones. Other companies have since the stuff, but my question is really around your 2 billion BOE resource number. It seems low versus the number of well locations. And I have a follow on.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Darrell. I do think that's a conservative number. And so we spoke about last quarter, that 2 billion BOE of resource, I think that's on a net basis. And I think when we look at it with the amount of BOEs in place for each section, I mean, we'
componenttext: Yes, this is Darrell. I do think that's a conservative number. And so we spoke about last quarter, that 2 billion BOE of resource, I think that's on a net basis. And I think when we look at it with the amount of BOEs in place for each section, I mean, we're looking at something less than a 5% recovery and we truly feel we'll get more a lot more than that. So I do think there's a lot more upside in the numbers that we've reported today.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, specifically, I guess, on the most of the folks has been on the World Cup for the obvious reasons. But on the shallower zones, the Avalon and the second Bone Spring, any sort of indications sort of EURs that you'd expect from those?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think all of those are going to be part of our future plan. When we talked about the resources last quarter, we are only talking about Wolfcamp. And if you think about largely what we're drilling today is down to the Wolfcamp in terms of making sure we
componenttext: I think all of those are going to be part of our future plan. When we talked about the resources last quarter, we are only talking about Wolfcamp. And if you think about largely what we're drilling today is down to the Wolfcamp in terms of making sure we retain acreage, we're having to drill down some of the deeper depths. So we haven't spent as much time on the Avalon and Bone Springs, but I can tell you we're very high on those as well. We think those EURs are still going to be 600-million-plus range in those sections, so they will be part of our future and part of our future resource but not quoted in the numbers we're talking today.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could, if I have one follow up on capital allocation over the next and acceleration over the next couple of years. I appreciate the comments in terms of potential acceleration into 2017. Should we think about -- I mean, how should we think abou
componenttext: Maybe if I could, if I have one follow up on capital allocation over the next and acceleration over the next couple of years. I appreciate the comments in terms of potential acceleration into 2017. Should we think about -- I mean, how should we think about the balance between capital acceleration and debt paydown or balance sheet repairs? Should we generally just view it as your paydown debt as debt maturities progress over the next couple of years? And anything incremental could go into capital acceleration? Or how do you look at acceleration versus balanced sheet repair, I guess, over the next 2 to 3 years?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just reiterate. I mean, what we see today is that the maturities in 2017 in which is the price is $750 million. The monetization proceeds will initially go to that. And then as we see what we believe to be an improving oil price scenario for
componenttext: Well, let me just reiterate. I mean, what we see today is that the maturities in 2017 in which is the price is $750 million. The monetization proceeds will initially go to that. And then as we see what we believe to be an improving oil price scenario for the reasons I've outlined, then the 2 principal onshore basins of DJ and Delaware is where we would anticipate if there is good economics, good cash cycling capabilities that we wouldn't -- that's where we would put our additional expenditures and additional capital. Maybe with that, in terms of just if there's questions around the debt, I'll be happy to let Bob address those. But if there's additional questions on the debt, is that what you're asking me?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think the general view is just how should we -- I mean, I think you have a longer-term target to get to -- to get back to kind of a 30% debt-to-cap ratio, I believe. And so how do you think about -- as you look forward over the next year, t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think the general view is just how should we -- I mean, I think you have a longer-term target to get to -- to get back to kind of a 30% debt-to-cap ratio, I believe. And so how do you think about -- as you look forward over the next year, then I get that this is highly dependent on oil prices as well, but how do you think about your ability to accelerate versus the desire to eventually kind of get the balance sheet back into the kind of long-term target ranges?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we use a variety of metrics beyond just debt to cap. And debt to cap is somewhat less relevant. The oil target is somewhat less relevant, given that with the way the commodity price have backed up, we and everyone else have taken a lot of write-down
componenttext: Well, we use a variety of metrics beyond just debt to cap. And debt to cap is somewhat less relevant. The oil target is somewhat less relevant, given that with the way the commodity price have backed up, we and everyone else have taken a lot of write-downs of assets on the balanced sheet that have affected that -- what that debt-to-cap number might look like in the future. But when you look at debt to cash flow in particular, when we look at debt per barrel and producing barrel, it is -- we feel that the balance sheet is not that far out of whack of where we'd like for it to be. The difference between the past is that we don't expect the commodity price recovery to, I don't know, $90, $100, or whatever we were facing at a point in time when debt-to-EBITDA metrics across the industry were so much lower. And so the way we're looking at it is to try to have -- try to match our pro forma metrics to our pro forma activity levels and that pro forma commodity prices I'll mention where we go back to work. So it's a bit of a moving target. What we know we will certainly we'll do was take -- is repay the $750 million of debt that we stated publicly repeatedly that we are going to repay the 2017 maturities. And we believe that there should be an opportunity to reduce gross debt further through some liability management programs around many of our smaller less liquid issues. But in many cases, the holders are very happy with those issues, and we certainly wouldn't expect to pay material premium just to retire them. We do have a put bond out there that is not callable, but it's quotable to us once a year. Certainly, there, you can negotiate around some of that type of debt if you want to take our gross debt number down further. But it's our clear intent, as we stated in the past, to continue to build cash and to ensure that we're reducing that net debt number that we continue to remain focused on liquidity, and we're very comfortable through liquidity position, a leverage position, allows us to accelerate drilling should the commodity price warranted. But to accelerate it within reason. We're talking in a hundreds of millions of dollars, not massive changes of about spending cash flow. We're pretty close even at current discretionary cash flow to spending within discretionary cash flow. So the delta here is asset sales. If we're successful with asset sale the way we have been, and then it gives us a lot of flexibility based on the commodity environment and outlook that we see at the time to moderately reduce leverage consistently with that commodity price environment and to moderately accelerate spending in places where we have really attractive returns to begin to move our production back to our growth and away from maintenance.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Maybe if I could, if I can follow up on some of the -- on the previous question on the Delaware Basin. We've seen great results as you guided across the Wolfcamp and you had 11,000, 10,000 for the long lateral I think in the Wolfcamp
componenttext: That's very helpful. Maybe if I could, if I can follow up on some of the -- on the previous question on the Delaware Basin. We've seen great results as you guided across the Wolfcamp and you had 11,000, 10,000 for the long lateral I think in the Wolfcamp that you brought on so far. Can you talk a little bit about what you're how much running room you think you have in terms of acreage that's conducive to 10,000 foot laterals? And then maybe as a follow-up to that as well on the second Bone Springs in the Avalon, any rough estimates as to how much of your acreage those horizons might be prevalent across?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just start with -- our focus is clearly going to be the Wolfcamp. And we've got -- a lot of our acreage that's conducive to at least mead, and in many cases, longs, but certainly not all of it. And we'll continue to look at ways at which we can acr
componenttext: Let me just start with -- our focus is clearly going to be the Wolfcamp. And we've got -- a lot of our acreage that's conducive to at least mead, and in many cases, longs, but certainly not all of it. And we'll continue to look at ways at which we can acreage and build that land position so that we can go with the longer laterals. But I think what you've seen over time is we started with many of the shorts, and today, our average is closer to the mids only because we've been able to do a number of  longs, some mids and some short. And so clearly, it's beneficial for us to do the longer laterals where we can, and we're looking at every opportunity where we can, like I said, trade acreage maybe as such we can get in that position. As far as Avalon and Bone Spring, again, I just reiterate, we're not focused on that as much right now. We've done some Bone Springs, but clearly, our price is  the Wolfcamp today. And whatever land position we create ourselves for the Wolfcamp, we'll get the benefit in both Avalon and Bone Springs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on some of the Wolfcamp question here. Can you just give us a bit of a lay of the land on how pervasive over your acreage is the 12 wells per section from a development perspective? Are there areas that our perspective or perspective
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on some of the Wolfcamp question here. Can you just give us a bit of a lay of the land on how pervasive over your acreage is the 12 wells per section from a development perspective? Are there areas that our perspective or perspective fewer [ph] in 12 wells per section? And then in the lower Wolfcamp, what's the timing and the potential area of significance from the testing that's currently ongoing?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, this Darrell again. As we look at it today and understand a lot of the drilling we're doing is to make sure we understand our entire acreage position. But if we -- I had to give you a number today, I'd say at least 3/4 of our Wolfcamp position
componenttext: Yes. Brian, this Darrell again. As we look at it today and understand a lot of the drilling we're doing is to make sure we understand our entire acreage position. But if we -- I had to give you a number today, I'd say at least 3/4 of our Wolfcamp position is what we would consider Tier 1 and would have at least 12 wells per section. I mean, some of those can be driven by economics. And so as prices go up, we might find ourselves with a lot more wells in those sections beyond the 12. So you could understand there's many benches inside the Wolfcamp. So as demonstrated on than 1 sheet, we're basically talking 4 wells per bench, but there clearly could be more than that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And the Lower Wolfcamp testing, how early significant would that be? And what's the timing there?
componenttext: Great. And the Lower Wolfcamp testing, how early significant would that be? And what's the timing there?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the case of the Lower, it's not as nearly prolific as what we see as the Wolfcamp A. But again, we hadn't done as much testing there, but clearly, it's going to be one of our targets in the future as well. But if you look at the Wolfcamp A in our case,
componenttext: In the case of the Lower, it's not as nearly prolific as what we see as the Wolfcamp A. But again, we hadn't done as much testing there, but clearly, it's going to be one of our targets in the future as well. But if you look at the Wolfcamp A in our case, we've got many benches in there, so it's our primary target.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Al, you highlighted your optimism for oil prices next year and your hope and interest in bringing back activity. Can you talk more specifically about what you're looking for to make that decision to bring production back on? How much of it would be ba
componenttext: And Al, you highlighted your optimism for oil prices next year and your hope and interest in bringing back activity. Can you talk more specifically about what you're looking for to make that decision to bring production back on? How much of it would be based on your own projections for commodity prices versus either realtime inventories? What the forward curve is saying or the front price, particularly given the lead time until you actually see that production come on for the drilling?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll give you my thoughts, Brian, on that. And simply, as we see U.S. oil production cascading towards that 8 million barrels a day that I made reference to in terms of where I think it will bottom out before it starts to go back up, that will, in m
componenttext: Well, I'll give you my thoughts, Brian, on that. And simply, as we see U.S. oil production cascading towards that 8 million barrels a day that I made reference to in terms of where I think it will bottom out before it starts to go back up, that will, in my estimation, help a lot. And if we -- on the demand side, we continue to see 1.2 million to 1.4 million barrels per day of demand per annum through the balance of the decade, I think the combination too are quite significant. It's been our view that we will see this price recovery win is demand-driven, but -- rather than supply constrained. Market forces don't work real well when you're relying on supply constraints to drive price, but I think if you think about it as a demand function that improves annually at the clip of 1.2 million to 1.3 million barrels a day, you can see pretty quickly that in an expanding demand relative to supply, demand is going to move up the curve and the intersection creates peak will put pressure on prices to move up to a level of around $60 a barrel. After that point, I mean, we're going to have to see what happens. From a, a demand standpoint; b, from a cost. Are we're going to see margin erosion? The returns in the cycling characteristics that we particularly follow with our onshore investing? Are distant going to be as attractive as we thought? So I'm not going to go beyond $60, but I think clearly, in our estimation, the ingredients are there for recovery to sustain $60 price environment for next year. Then I probably been as big a bear around oil expectations as anyone since early 2015. And I think with this, if we continue to see the characteristics I just laid out, continue to be prevalent in the market, that will be a great indication to us for what we want to do. Looking at the forward curve, I think you know us well as I do that's a little fragile. And as you look out further, particularly in light of the world we live in today and the lack of real -- lack of players in the market for the forward curve, it looks flat for a reason because we don't have the same participants in the curve today that we had 5 years or certainly 10 years ago. So the curve itself probably is not going to be as much of an indicator of activity as the other things I just made reference to.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Cameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Cameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Al, can I just go back to the $60 number? You previously said margins, kind of what drive your decisions. So can you talk about if we're in the 60, would you expect service cost to close that gap on the margin? Or how should we think about that dynamic?
componenttext: Al, can I just go back to the $60 number? You previously said margins, kind of what drive your decisions. So can you talk about if we're in the 60, would you expect service cost to close that gap on the margin? Or how should we think about that dynamic?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I may very well be wrong, but I don't see from, call it, $43 today to $60 a lot of service cost price inflation. I do think that as we approach $60, we'll start to see it, depending upon the activity in the principal basins that will be driving our
componenttext: David, I may very well be wrong, but I don't see from, call it, $43 today to $60 a lot of service cost price inflation. I do think that as we approach $60, we'll start to see it, depending upon the activity in the principal basins that will be driving our U.S. oil -- our U.S. production. We're continuing, I think as the industry, to see price concessions from service cost today. I think it will take awhile for activity levels and the use of services to put a lot of pressure on having service cost go up. At some point, service cost will go up. But I think if you think about it the way I think about it from a margin perspective, we don't anticipate a lot of wellhead margin erosion between here and $60.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then back to the Delaware. One of the concerns, I guess, has been capacity and constraints and the ability to get production on the basin. I look at your numbers, it looks like you exited at a higher rate than your average for th
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then back to the Delaware. One of the concerns, I guess, has been capacity and constraints and the ability to get production on the basin. I look at your numbers, it looks like you exited at a higher rate than your average for the quarter. Can you just talk about how much running room as far as just pipeline capacity and takeaway infrastructure of debt limits? to take later this year if oil heads back to $60, how much more room do you have to allocate into the Delaware?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Darrell. At this point, we see no constraints. We haven't seen a sign of it, and we don't expect to. I think there's a lot of systems being built out inside WES. We're expanding our capacity everyday, so we can don't see that to be a proble
componenttext: David, this is Darrell. At this point, we see no constraints. We haven't seen a sign of it, and we don't expect to. I think there's a lot of systems being built out inside WES. We're expanding our capacity everyday, so we can don't see that to be a problem anytime soon.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Al, just pulling together everything that we just heard. Firstly on the 8 million barrels a day that you see the U.S. production level reaching, what's the time frame for that? And the follow-up is, it feels and looks very much on this result as if you're
componenttext: Al, just pulling together everything that we just heard. Firstly on the 8 million barrels a day that you see the U.S. production level reaching, what's the time frame for that? And the follow-up is, it feels and looks very much on this result as if you're balanced now cash flow CapEx with flat volumes of around $45 to $55 a barrel. Firstly, if we do the lower than that, is there more to do with the recently since we start raising that? And secondly, if we progress there as you anticipate from $45 to date-ish to $60, is that move then a debt pay down move until you restart growth at $60? Or is there sort of a progression in there?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me try to take those as best I can. It's -- the timing for 8 million barrels a day, I'm no better at projecting that than a lot of people pay money just to do that by themselves in the vacuum of their own thoughts. But our view is it can happen
componenttext: Well, let me try to take those as best I can. It's -- the timing for 8 million barrels a day, I'm no better at projecting that than a lot of people pay money just to do that by themselves in the vacuum of their own thoughts. But our view is it can happen as early as late this year. And that's why I made the comment earlier. We think it's likely, and we can see a sustained price environment of $60 developing later this year. Now for reasons that I can't quite explain, but it takes a little bit longer to get to 8 million. That could be pushed into 2017, but you know better than I do how capital-intensive our industry is, particularly for unconventional development and the sustaining and production levels. And we, as the industry, have not been investing at a level that allows production to be held flat. Just exactly how fast it cascades is sort of a question, I think, each other need to watch. But my comment to you would be I think it could be as early as the fourth quarter, and that's the basis by which I'm making my comments. Because I still see the demand side using IEA as the basis for that wit having 1 to 2, maybe 1.2 million to 1.4 million barrels per annum of additional demand, yet it will be a demand recovery, not a supply recovery. And it's really the basis of that demand expansion or the large and increasing portion of the pie I think will give us some comfort around how that actually will be sustained. As it relates to capital planning, you're right. This is not a step function. It's not linear and it's probably more likely a lot. As we approach $60, we'll invest more at the will at $43-ish and in terms of where WTI is today. So we're already sort of telling you today that we anticipate with improvements that we think are forecasted, but we will start to reallocate some of our monetization proceeds as we've described on this call. I think if we -- as we get into our planning for capital for next year and think about that in conjunction with the discussions with our Board, the more we feel comfortable about that sustained $60 price environment, the more likely you will see us increase in capital, particularly in the areas that we're talking about on the margin, increasing capital to in anticipation of a price recovery. I hope that helps. You had a question about -- I'm sorry, you had a question about debt. Let me Paul answer that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I guess -- Paul, one thing I want to point out though is you asked if prices move the other way. If we were wrong, and prices go down, does that mean we increase debt? Absolutely not. In fact, we continue to reduce debt through the asset monetizatio
componenttext: Paul, I guess -- Paul, one thing I want to point out though is you asked if prices move the other way. If we were wrong, and prices go down, does that mean we increase debt? Absolutely not. In fact, we continue to reduce debt through the asset monetization proceeds. So prices go down, the asset monetization proceeds got a debt reduction. As prices go up, we first reduce the debt along the lines we described earlier and then we start to put the dollars back to work the way Al just described.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And the follow-up, the obvious follow up is just can you talk about hedging and all that?
componenttext: Helpful. And the follow-up, the obvious follow up is just can you talk about hedging and all that?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've -- as you guys saw some of the information, we've layered in some gas hedges. I think if you look at the structure, there's three-way colors. That starts and foremost, starts our views on natural gas, but they're not particularly bullish. But I thin
componenttext: We've -- as you guys saw some of the information, we've layered in some gas hedges. I think if you look at the structure, there's three-way colors. That starts and foremost, starts our views on natural gas, but they're not particularly bullish. But I think we've left ourselves some upside to benefit in particular with our associated gas production. That remains a pretty significant part of the portfolio. We have not focused on layering on any oil hedges. We don't like the structure of the market today to go ahead and lock in prices at all. And we've never looked at hedging as a way to justify drilling activity at any given price. We've instead looked at hedges as a way of providing some moderate protection of the balance sheet, reducing volatility of our cash flow relative to the commodity price environment. So we've as we've done historically, we'd probably like to win some more oil hedges with the right price and we like the shape of the curve. And I think from a gas standpoint, whether we do anymore or not just also remains to be seen. We're pretty comfortable of what we've got done for '17 at this stage.

componenttextpreview: Well, you are one of those people who watches everything, so I really do appreciate that about you. Sometimes we put press releases up and wonder if people look at them in any detail. So thanks for the question. Yes, we really felt like adding someone lik
componenttext: Well, you are one of those people who watches everything, so I really do appreciate that about you. Sometimes we put press releases up and wonder if people look at them in any detail. So thanks for the question. Yes, we really felt like adding someone like David to our Board was very important from a skill set. Dave has got a long career at Florida and then later at. With Dave, project management, understanding how big boxes need to be built, how the project management needs to be executed. I think his experience will be quite helpful as we approach and consider the day when we take FID in Mozambique. And he will also be a wonderful board member for management to be able to go to and use as a resource as we consider that decision. So not to say that we don't have Board members today that are helpful in that area. We do, but we recognize the challenges associated with taking FID in Mozambique fairly significant. And being able to add a board member like David with his skill set, we're very, very fortunate to be able to do that. And thank you, John, for asking the question.

componenttext: Okay. How much of your savings, especially onshore, do you think will be sustained because of change of process and design, going forward?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to take this in part with Darrell because some of the process changes are going to be able -- are going to be such as we can retain. Some of the efficiencies that we have today in certain field is going to be very high as much as the Delaware, I
componenttext: I'm going to take this in part with Darrell because some of the process changes are going to be able -- are going to be such as we can retain. Some of the efficiencies that we have today in certain field is going to be very high as much as the Delaware, I mean, the DJ Basin. But I think what we're seeing, John, is that it's still a fairly aggressive service environment for what the service providers need and want in the way of market share. And we've got a new participant back in that market, given the unsuccessful consolidation of Halliburton and  Baker House. And I think you just have to appreciate in the near term that is the new dynamic into the marketplace that was not there earlier this year. And, Darrell, with that, won't you take please take it to the next step?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, if I have a guess, I would say we're going to at least maintain 2/3 of what we've been able to achieve. If you just recall what we've gone through almost every quarter, as we continuously are finding more efficient ways to drill and complete these w
componenttext: John, if I have a guess, I would say we're going to at least maintain 2/3 of what we've been able to achieve. If you just recall what we've gone through almost every quarter, as we continuously are finding more efficient ways to drill and complete these wells. And even the facilities side, we're getting better at that. So no doubt, the cost structure coming down has helped, but our efficiency has probably been the biggest driver. And with that, I would say that just because we're here today doesn't mean we won't continue to find different ways to increase our efficiencies and what we're doing to help offset any pressure we may see going forward.

componenttextpreview: Yes. We would call iDUCs and I think we came in the year with about 2 30, and I would argue we still have roughly the same. If you look at something, to your point at Maverick, a lot of that have to do on the cost saving measure. A lot of this was done ac
componenttext: Yes. We would call iDUCs and I think we came in the year with about 2 30, and I would argue we still have roughly the same. If you look at something, to your point at Maverick, a lot of that have to do on the cost saving measure. A lot of this was done actually in '15. We took the opportunity to tie back to some of the existing equipment as opposed to building new, and so some of that got delayed, and that's what you're seeing there. It really didn't affect our numbers, but I think from a practical standpoint to address your on iDUCs, other wells that we usually have in the queue in terms of their drill and completed. So we have probably an excess of 500 wells like that. And so I think from a practical standpoint, as Al is suggesting, as we look forward into the end of the year and into next year and we have the opportunity to stand up rigs and additional crews, you will see that all of that really becomes the inventory in which we work off of. And in some cases, it has to do with simultaneous operations, some of it has got to have to do with what we want to test, so that we can additional information in places like the Delaware. And so I think, again, looking forward, I would just look at it from a standpoint we've got about 500 wells and inventory like that that we'll be using as we increase our programs, going forward.

componenttext: Just two quick questions on the Delaware Basin. First, just wanted to talk a little bit about the completion design change. You guys have made fairly significant strides in optimization since 2014. I think the last kind of that we sdaw was really around early 2015. And then there were some discussion in the press releases around that EUR progressing higher late last year, but I'm just curious around the current design and thoughts on the rate of change on the EUR side.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Matt, I'd say it's fair to say we have made a lot of improvements. But I tell you, we're learning all the time. We're in the midst right now of a 20 well test, if you will. All-in-one particular area where, again, the reason for the test is more for
componenttext: Yes. Matt, I'd say it's fair to say we have made a lot of improvements. But I tell you, we're learning all the time. We're in the midst right now of a 20 well test, if you will. All-in-one particular area where, again, the reason for the test is more for the completions and the drilling side of it. So we still have a lot to learn, but as we bury some of these stages, some of the sand we're pumping, even some of the water we're pumping in these intervals, we're learning all the time. But I think it is fair to say as we've got additional production data, we do feel the EURs continue to increase. And so as I pointed out last year, while these wells that have been online now for a while, we're seeing 800 million to 1 million barrels of oil, so we're feeling really good about that. But there's still a lot to learn and understand we've got a huge acreage position, so we're going to see some variance across this as well.

componenttext: First on Avalon, you won't see us doing anymore work on that this year to my earlier point. In a lot of cases where we're preserving our leases, we've got to really drill down the Wolfcamp, and that's really our big prize. What we've seen in the past is these wells are sort of in the order of 1,500 BOE per day wells, 800 million -- or 800,000 well EURs. So we think this really going to be a productive area, but you're just not going to see us playing it anytime soon.

When we move into next year, I think we're pretty well situated. And that only improves if we're allocating capital to our growth place in the U.S.

Again with [indiscernible] we get complete some wells in the third quarter. But the bulk of them were actually completed last year, and the reason they came on in the first and second quarter, a lot of that had to do with trying to tie back into existing infrastructures as opposed to doing new 2 [ph] wells. So we've got delayed a little bit, but if you look at us today, we have no rigs, no completion.
[Audio Gap]

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Anadarko Petroleum Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to John. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter 2016 conference calls.I would like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financia
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Rocco. Good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter 2016 conference calls.
I would like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financial measures, and be aware that a number of factors could cause results to differ materially from what we discuss today. So I encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and the GAAP reconciliations located on our website and attached to yesterday's earnings release.
In just a moment, I'll turn the call over to Al Walker for some brief opening remarks, but first, I'd like to thank Jeremy Smith for his contributions he's made to the IR group over the last couple of years. Jeremy is now in his new role as Vice President of Mozambique project finance.
And along with that, I'd like to introduce Pete Zagrzecki, who has joined IR and will be available to assist with questions later this afternoon, along with the rest of our team.
I'll also remind you that we have a lot of additional detail in our quarterly ops report available on our website. And following Al's prepared remarks, we'll open it up for questions with our executive team. Al?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning. As we turn the corner into the second half of 2016, we've made exceptional progress on the goals we established for this year of enhancing value, strengthening the balanced sheet, high grading the portfolio and reducing cos
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning. As we turn the corner into the second half of 2016, we've made exceptional progress on the goals we established for this year of enhancing value, strengthening the balanced sheet, high grading the portfolio and reducing cost.
In terms of enhancing value, our operating organization has done a tremendous job achieving several milestones during the quarter. As you can see in our operations report available online, we had outstanding performance in the Gulf of Mexico. This is an area, where we hold several competitive advantages, a successful exploration track record, an industry-leading project management capability and a large operated infrastructure position.
Our Gulf assets provide us a capital efficient value driver, and our record production achievements at constitution and K2 are great examples of that. Our operations at Lucius facility also achieved record production during the quarter, with oil volumes exceeding nameplate capacity. As I suspect you know in our ops report, we drove another appraisal well at Shenandoah. The Shenandoah 5 well encountered more than 1,000 feet of net oil play and expanded the eastern extent of the field with planning of the Shen 6 now underway.
We have a 33% working interest in Shenandoah after participating in a pref right process, and through that process, we picked up some additional blocks and exploration opportunities at no cost.
Record production levels are also achieved in the DJ and the Delaware Basins, and we're able to increase our activity over our initial expectations, while still keeping capital expenditures within guidance.
In the Delaware Basin, we have further reduced our DC&E cost per well and improved our drilling cycle times, while advancing our delineation program across a very large acreage position.
In the DJ Basin, we achieved record production, while lowering our LOE by about 15% year-over-year. Our outstanding operating results are complemented by another year of strong monetization results. In the first quarter, we announced approximately $1.3 billion of monetizations. Since then, we've achieved and received an additional $1.2 billion of proceeds and executed a successful secondary offering of WGP units.
We now expect total proceeds to be at or above $3.5 billion for the full year. So far this year, through the cost structure improvements I have mentioned as well as the dividend reduction and monetization efforts, we have significantly strengthened the balance sheet.
We've done this by retiring $3 billion of near-term maturities with our first quarter '16 common issuance and planning to retire the remaining $750 million of 2017 maturities from our monetization proceeds.
The cautious approach we outlined for oil price recovery at the beginning of 2015 has played out much as we anticipated. It now appears U.S. also flat peaked at around 9.6 million barrels per day, and we expect it to bottom out around 8 million barrels per day, all the while with global demand now exceeding expectations.
Given this dynamic, I am now encouraged that a sustained $60 oil price environment is likely to emerge as we move into 2017. This price level should provide the necessary cash margins and resulting cash cycle improvements to encourage us to accelerate activity and achieve strong returns. In this scenario, we would evaluate redeploying some of the incremental proceeds from asset sales towards our highest quality U.S. onshore assets later this year.
Our unique positions in the DJ and Delaware Basins, combined with the tieback opportunities in the Gulf of Mexico, give us strong line of sight for attractive, capital efficient, short cycle oil investments as crude prices recover.
With that, we would love to take your questions, and thanks for joining us this morning.

componenttextpreview: If I could, this is Al. I think, a lot of that's going to be very depended upon what we anticipate to be a recovery in oil prices, but we're going to watch that pretty closely before we commit beyond the comments we're giving you this morning. But I'm --
componenttext: If I could, this is Al. I think, a lot of that's going to be very depended upon what we anticipate to be a recovery in oil prices, but we're going to watch that pretty closely before we commit beyond the comments we're giving you this morning. But I'm -- for the first time since January of 2015, I think we see a window to a better oil prices. And I foreshadow this a little bit at the Wells Conference a few months ago, when I made the comments there that we anticipate we'd have a let down as the market tried to absorb the 3 million barrels associated with disruptions from Venezuela, Nigeria and Canada. And as the market went through that congestion, we've -- we're going to see the let down that we're seeing right now. And I think once we get behind -- we get that behind us, to use an economics term, [indiscernible]. We think we're looking at the sustained $60 oil price environment for next year. But I think to the question you're asking and do we see greater evidence that our thoughts are in fact true, we'll be a little slow and probably more likely to be willing to communicate that with greater clarity next quarter.

componenttext: Yes, Evan, we're real pleased with what we saw in the #5 well. Not surprised, but we are very pleased to see it commence. We had predicted it would 1,040-plus feet of pay. We're about 0.5 mile east of the #2 well, and then we're going to move farther east and down dip with the #6. With your question of what else is going to take, we're really have to see what the #6 tells us. If the #6 comes in as we project with the oil-water contacts, we'll probably need to then do a sidetrack out of that, try to go up dip, get in full oil column in that. And -- so the ultimate planning has to be after #6. We've got a lot of work that's going on right now though related to how we might develop this field. But again, we're still in the appraisal mode, and so we need to get the rest of the information in front of us.

componenttext: Well, I think all things Bob just gave you are going to kind of ingredients. That's going to be important to understand. I'd point to Mad Dog, which I believe VP has publicly discussed the fact they're going to take a decision on this year, and they've indicated that sanction is likely. And I think there's just a couple of takeaways from that, not necessarily related to Shenandoah, one is they reduced the production solution cost from $20 billion to $8 billion, so that helps with the economics. And two, they think they've got an estimate also in recovery. That's pretty significant. And so the EUR combined with a lower cost probably gives you a threshold for price that would not have been anticipated a few years ago for sanctioning. So we're hopeful that some of those ingredients will work into our favor as that decision comes to us over the next couple of years.

componenttext: Al, one of the things, I guess, that makes guidance a little challenging at least in terms of the production outlook, is the tieback schedule, but you've obviously been quite successful in the Gulf of Mexico. And what -- how does the relative priority of tieback stock up relative to adding capital onshore? I've got a follow-up, please.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you go back to our March presentation, the allocation that we've laid out at that time gives you a pretty clear understanding. And I think the only thing we would say that would change from that is simply if we find ourselves in an improv
componenttext: Well, I think if you go back to our March presentation, the allocation that we've laid out at that time gives you a pretty clear understanding. And I think the only thing we would say that would change from that is simply if we find ourselves in an improving oil price environment, which I said earlier I think is very likely, we will deploy that initially for the debt retirement for the maturities in 2017, and then we'll look to the 2 principle onshore assets in the DJ and the Delaware Basins for that capital. That aside, Doug, I can't see any other additional percentage allocation going differently than what we laid out in March, and it's too early to say at this juncture what we'll do for 2017.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate the attempt, the answer. I want a second follow-up, if I may on the Delaware Basin. I know there's been a lot of chatter, but further on, if you could ever see an opportunity to acquire your partner's interest there. But if I may, I wan
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate the attempt, the answer. I want a second follow-up, if I may on the Delaware Basin. Because my understanding is that you may end up with higher working interest in some of those incremental wells.

componenttext: Well, I'm going to let Darrell fill in some of the details, but that's a question it's really hard to answer, because every package of AFEs that they send to us or we send to them causes that sort of change the landscape a little bit. We don't have a great insight into what sort of plans they have for developing those wells if they want to push AFEs towards us on. And ours, in terms of what we're planning to do, I think by evidence of the fact we're standing up a few more rigs, speaks to our confidence in the field as well as gives you some insight what we think the oil prices are going to do. I think beyond that, let me let Darrell fill you in just a little bit more on the details. But philosophically, Doug, I don't think it's likely that our partner there is a seller as best we can tell it. It doesn't seem like they're motivated to do so. And frankly, given the quality of the asset, I can understand that.

componenttext: Yes. Doug, probably to follow on with that. From a working interest standpoint, I think assuming a 50-50 is about where we're going to end up, and really are today, I don't see that really changing because of the additional drilling that's going on. I can't speak to the future and the balance of the year, but I can tell you that yesterday, we got 6 rigs stood up and Shell has 2 rigs stood up.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about your view on the A&D marketplace. And specifically, you guys have been very successful selling assets, but at some point, there was also a talk of perhaps buying in the Delaware Basin. So could you talk about what you're seeing on th
componenttext: I wanted to ask about your view on the A&D marketplace. And specifically, you guys have been very successful selling assets, but at some point, there was also a talk of perhaps buying in the Delaware Basin. So could you talk about what you're seeing on the asset sale side? And what implications that might have for your ability to add in the Delaware Basin?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think Bob Gwin is probably in the better position to answer that for you. And I'll just say before I pass this to him, I think he and Jerry Windlinger and the folks who have been working that for us over the last several years, particularly in the
componenttext: Sure. I think Bob Gwin is probably in the better position to answer that for you. And I'll just say before I pass this to him, I think he and Jerry Windlinger and the folks who have been working that for us over the last several years, particularly in the last 24 months when the market conditions have been pretty challenging, have done an exceptional job. And we often talk about it being a core strength of ours in order to how we manage our A&D portfolio. And how well, I think, we can do it even in times of challenging and stressful pricing. I know there's been a lot of investor concern that can you continue to sell assets in a very depressed market? And I couldn't be happier with what I think Bob and Jerry have done in the last couple of years. So, Bob, let me turn it over to you to answer the question specifically.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. Charles, it's really a market today where we are buying and selling, but in a lot of small transaction. So it's things that are small enough, they generally don't get reported. The ones that we're summarizing in our asset divesture program w
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. Charles, it's really a market today where we are buying and selling, but in a lot of small transaction. So it's things that are small enough, they generally don't get reported. The ones that we're summarizing in our asset divesture program were generally our larger transactions. Or in some cases like even recently in the Permian, where we saw some acreage that we had in the portfolio, felt like we wouldn't get to that acreage for quite a while and that it didn't necessarily fit as well relative to our development plans. And so we saw it as unique opportunity to sell something. I think it's fair to say that the market should continue to be receptive based on the dynamics we're seeing. It should continue to be receptive for the types of assets that we're bringing to market. Those assets share a common characteristic that they're generally not going to attract capital in our portfolio, really virtually any gas price. And I mentioned the gas price because they're mostly dry gas assets. We will retain a lot of exposure to gas through the associated gas of our 2 primary U.S. onshore assets. But the dry gas assets have pretty good economics, intrinsic economics. It's strip pricing. And so we've seen buyers that see it as a neat assets relative to the size of their firm and the types of things they're trying to do, not as attractive to us. They make a lot of sense for us to sell. On the margin, we, however, are a buyer of assets. And if they're priced right and if they're in the right location, and really, the 3 core areas where we're putting capital and we believe we have competitive advantages in the Delaware, and in Wattenberg and in the Gulf of Mexico or places where we continue to look at packages. We look at packages elsewhere, but in many cases, we don't see what our competitive advantage will be or what the synergy is with our existing operations. And so we have not been successful bidders on those packages, where we've chosen to submit a bid.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful detail. And then picking up on -- perhaps on that thread of the Wattenberg and DJ Basin, I want to say it was maybe 1.5 years or 2 years ago that you started the conference call talking about the enigma or the puzzle of what was goi
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful detail. And then picking up on -- perhaps on that thread of the Wattenberg and DJ Basin, I want to say it was maybe 1.5 years or 2 years ago that you started the conference call talking about the enigma or the puzzle of what was going on with the California -- or actually, the Colorado ballot initiatives. And it's a little different story this time around, but it feels like déjà vu for a lot of people. And the question is -- the question on some people's mind is are we going to be stuck in this kind of loop in Colorado? So can you offer your thoughts on that front and on the political process environment in Colorado? And perhaps if that interacts with your decision or your future decisions to accelerate in the DJ?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me just a comment or 2 on that. One is we take what we do in the DJ Basin and Colorado broadly defined very seriously, and we try very hard everyday to be a part of educating the electric in the state. We feel like with knowledge of and understa
componenttext: Okay. Let me just a comment or 2 on that. One is we take what we do in the DJ Basin and Colorado broadly defined very seriously, and we try very hard everyday to be a part of educating the electric in the state. We feel like with knowledge of and understanding and appreciation for what the industry does and how we're doing it and the issues associated with what setbacks really mean that an educated voter is more likely to understand why this is important and why the ballot initiative has structured, particularly this year, would do so much damage to the state. We think that's very important. We see both the U.S. cylinders from the state as well as the governor being very understanding of this issue. In fact, the Governor Hickenlooper was on CNBC earlier this morning, and I think he's considered one of the better governors in the United States. And certainly, he's very thoughtful around these issues being a part of the oil and gas industry much earlier in his career as a geologist. So I think politically, we have a very good understanding from both a Democratic governor, a Democratic senator and a Republican senator. And I think the politics in the state are such that we just need to continue to do what we can do with the help of other industry participants to educate the voters in a way when they do go to the ballot and if the ballot were, in fact, on the docket for this fall, they understand what they're voting on. And we take that very seriously every day as well as notable on a lot of other companies. And I think to that end, that is the best way I can address your question.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
