componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all your help. If I could dig into your activity here going forward. One thing that was certainly different about this quarter versus last several quarters is that there's not a whole lot of conversation on DUC sand specifically iDUCs. Can you
componenttext: Thanks for all your help. If I could dig into your activity here going forward. One thing that was certainly different about this quarter versus last several quarters is that there's not a whole lot of conversation on DUC sand specifically iDUCs. Can you give us a general sense on how you view that [ph] if it was formerly known as iDUCs with respect to how you deploy capital her e going forward?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, first of all, it is DUCs season, [indiscernible] be a joke. I think as we move into the balance of the year, I mean, I made reference to the fact that we're going to use some of the capital that -- particularly in the DJ Basin. We've talked
componenttext: Well, I mean, first of all, it is DUCs season, [indiscernible] be a joke. I think as we move into the balance of the year, I mean, I made reference to the fact that we're going to use some of the capital that -- particularly in the DJ Basin. We've talked about increasing there another 50 completions just based upon the capital we've saved by being more efficient. So as we move through this, we're moving into a higher-price environment. We think, fundamentally, we should continue to see improvement in the quarters ahead. As a result, you'll see us continue to work more to, I'll call it, a working inventory level of drilled but uncompleted. It's not an abnormal level of that. Because I think, as each of the people in this call know quite well, I mean, we have an ongoing sort of like working capital position with respect to drilled uncompleted locations. So it's not like it'll be completely eliminated. But I think given the price environment that we see ourselves in today and projected in the coming quarters, we'll convert more as appropriate of that current inventory into completions. But it's not a marked change. I think it's just what we've been trying to say through the course of the year that we will, at the appropriate time, start to convert our drilled and uncompleted locations into opportunities for production. And Darrell, please add to that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott, to some extent, we've done that at Wattenberg, where we've actually -- we were down to one rig here in both the second and third quarters. We had 1.5 completion crews out there, and so we've gone through some of the -- at one time, what we wou
componenttext: Yes. Scott, to some extent, we've done that at Wattenberg, where we've actually -- we were down to one rig here in both the second and third quarters. We had 1.5 completion crews out there, and so we've gone through some of the -- at one time, what we would've considered iDUCs. But I'll tell you, it's -- it probably makes sense today as our activities pick up and our number of rigs is that we get away from iDUCs, and it's really an inventory. When you look at Delaware, we were at 6 rigs for the summer. We picked up a seventh rig here in the third quarter, and we picked up an eighth already in October and we'd like to pick up a ninth. So as we look at our inventory, it's all becoming one, and we just look at that as wells to be completed. So I'd sort of get away from the iDUCs. We had the same issues going on in Wattenberg where we had, I guess, the one rig, and we now picked up 2 here in October. And it's very likely we'll pick up another rig, if not 2, here before the end of the year as we go into 2017 and move our program forward. So again, I'd just caution you to maybe get away from iDUCs and look at it as just our inventory and part of our rigs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just to clarify, and you mentioned -- it's sounds like a little bit more price-related. Was there a little bit of -- post the acquisition of the offshore stuff, was there a little bit of balance sheet in there? Or is that totally a
componenttext: That's great. And then just to clarify, and you mentioned -- it's sounds like a little bit more price-related. Was there a little bit of -- post the acquisition of the offshore stuff, was there a little bit of balance sheet in there? Or is that totally a price-related decision when you decided to kind of work through those iDUCs?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's been more price-oriented. If you think back to where we were in early -- in the first quarter and the things that the industry in general is dealing with, I think we, along with others, just didn't feel a need or compelled to bring these into com
componenttext: No, it's been more price-oriented. If you think back to where we were in early -- in the first quarter and the things that the industry in general is dealing with, I think we, along with others, just didn't feel a need or compelled to bring these into completion until we believe it was appropriate from a standpoint of where prices are now. You could argue one way or the other where you think that was a good strategy or bad. I think from our perspective, we thought it was a much better strategy to bring these into completion when oil is around $50 versus $30.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then as a follow-up, Constellation, that acquisition in the offshore. That looks pretty interesting. Could you give a little color around that opportunity? What you all think you acquired in terms of what this thing can produce and
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then as a follow-up, Constellation, that acquisition in the offshore. That looks pretty interesting. Could you give a little color around that opportunity? What you all think you acquired in terms of what this thing can produce and the cost of the doing something like that?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the attractive things about the Freeport McMoran Oil & Gas transaction beyond being able to increase if not double our position in Lucius, was being able to look at the infrastructure that we were taking on for additional tiebacks that were c
componenttext: Well, one of the attractive things about the Freeport McMoran Oil & Gas transaction beyond being able to increase if not double our position in Lucius, was being able to look at the infrastructure that we were taking on for additional tiebacks that were currently in inventory from a Freeport, or through being able to provide production-handling agreements to third parties who need to come across the platform in order for something to be productive. I mean, we've gone from 7 operated facilities in the Gulf of Mexico to 10 now. Our ability to leverage those into opportunities like Constellation, I don't think that's going to be a one and done. I think we're going to see more of that. And maybe Darrell, if you don't mind, elaborate just a little bit.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the case of constellation, the Seal Hopkins discovery by BP. And where they stood at the plant, it's not very expensive development but it was hard to do a Greenfield there. And with our Constitution platform just miles away, we were able to lever
componenttext: Yes. In the case of constellation, the Seal Hopkins discovery by BP. And where they stood at the plant, it's not very expensive development but it was hard to do a Greenfield there. And with our Constitution platform just miles away, we were able to leverage our way in there for third working interest and we gave a PHA across our facility. And so you'll see us drilling our first development well here next year in '17, and we should see production in '18. But again, you talk compliancing. We would expect these wells to produce 15,000 barrels a day-type wells. Exactly how many n need to drill, we haven't worked through that. But it was be a great opportunity for us, like Al said, because of our infrastructure. It provided a great opportunity for us to sort of leverage our way into this and so were the operator with the BP being the other 2/3.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, congrats on your career and responsiveness to all of us. Al, your acreage position in the Delaware in addition to the West ownership with Anadarko, your unique position to discuss the infrastructure needed to ramp up in the Delaware. I wondered if y
componenttext: John, congrats on your career and responsiveness to all of us. Al, your acreage position in the Delaware in addition to the West ownership with Anadarko, your unique position to discuss the infrastructure needed to ramp up in the Delaware. I wondered if you could give us an update on the midstream CapEx that you see needed in the Delaware to meet Anadarko's needs. Whether you see any pipeline or gathering constraints at Anadarko and others ramp up seemingly pretty aggressively. How the differences made -- how there may be differences or similarities for Anadarko's specific experience versus industries?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Brian, thanks for asking that question. I think we did in the DJ Basin was for us a bit of a road map for what we're trying to do in the Delaware Basin. The difference being the Delaware Basin, Don Sinclair is using a lot of third party money. And b
componenttext: Well, Brian, thanks for asking that question. I think we did in the DJ Basin was for us a bit of a road map for what we're trying to do in the Delaware Basin. The difference being the Delaware Basin, Don Sinclair is using a lot of third party money. And by that, I mean, we're transmitting or processing volumes for third parties. As a result, it's not as capital-intensive net to Anadarko as it was in the DJ Basin where we were largely, if not in some cases, exclusively the equity behind system. So consequently here, we're a bit more of a third party provider of processing and transmission services or gathering. And consequently, the net capital requirements for Anadarko is a lot less as we take where we believe is the playbook in the DJ and put it work in the Delaware. That's why you've seen us make acquisitions like we did. Took about 2 years ago. That's why you've seen us organically add to what we have as well as what we acquired. And that's why we've been fairly focused on these various ramps we planned to increase our production and processing capabilities. Darrell has a fairly aggressive plan for drilling upstream dollars behind these plants, and he has, I'd say, a more modest need on capital as it relates to midstream. Darrell?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only comment I'd make is not without a challenge. Whether it's being done by Midstream or West, we are investing in the infrastructure, and where we can take advantage of third party opportunities, were doing it. But if you, again, going back to the o
componenttext: The only comment I'd make is not without a challenge. Whether it's being done by Midstream or West, we are investing in the infrastructure, and where we can take advantage of third party opportunities, were doing it. But if you, again, going back to the offshore port, you see the scattered fashion in which we're trying to delineate the field, it does create some challenges on the facility side. And so we'll still be tracking some of our volumes, but the extent we can. It's giving us the opportunity to really extend that footprint. I think from a bigger picture standpoint, as we look into '17, your question on capacity constraints, we don't see it. We think we have no issues getting out of Basin in '17. Even with the aggressive program, we'd probably come into the year with.

I guess just shifting more to the outlook for 2017 now that we're still some months away from when you would have your guidance, but can you just kind of talk about how you're thinking about how the capital program and, ultimately, your expectations for growth would differ if, let's say, we're sitting here in 3 or 4 months at a similar oil price to the $46 to $47 we're at versus if we're $5 or $10 higher?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, I don't think it will really affect the principal investing strategy that we were talking about this morning. I don't mean to sound like a broken record, but it's going to be Delaware, DJ and deepwater Gulf of Mexico that's going to take on the lio
componenttext: Brian, I don't think it will really affect the principal investing strategy that we were talking about this morning. I don't mean to sound like a broken record, but it's going to be Delaware, DJ and deepwater Gulf of Mexico that's going to take on the lion's share of our capital. And let's call it a fairly static or environment for operating conditions. So consequently, our ability to put more capital to work, either through cash flow or through cash on hand, we have a lot of flexibility. I'm real proud of what Bob Glennon, a lot of Our corporate Development folks working with our asset teams have been able to accomplish with the monetizations we've achieved to date and things we hope to do in the future. So whether it's cash flow or the use of cash at the point in time, we have the capacity today to do things that we've talked about wanting to be in a position to go into '17, believing that fundamentally, we should see better price support for oil. And if that's the case, I think you'll see us cycle to cash faster. You'll see us likely increase the types of things we've been talking about in the Delaware Basin first. I think Darrell would probably stand up rigs in the Delaware had a DJ to some extent. There's a lot of opportunity we see in the near term in the Delaware before we go in our full development mode. But Darrell, please add to that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're right. That's my comment. We've picked up that eighth rig in Delaware and look to pick up a ninth here shortly. But let's not take away from DJ. We went to 3 rigs now. We'll probably pick up a fourth and fifth rig potentially by the end
componenttext: No, I think you're right. That's my comment. We've picked up that eighth rig in Delaware and look to pick up a ninth here shortly. But let's not take away from DJ. We went to 3 rigs now. We'll probably pick up a fourth and fifth rig potentially by the end of the year. We've gone out and said that we'd look to grow oil 10% to 12% in a $50 to $60 world. If it's a little bit less than that, I would guess it to just drop a little bit more. It just depends on how we're going to spend the cash on hand. But in this case, I think you can expect between the 3Ds that we will see considerable oil growth over the next 5 years.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know you know this, but we have a very high oil cut in our position with Delaware. This is not a lot of natural gas, a little bit of liquids. This is a big cut that's oil that gives us tremendous economics at the well head and as a result, gives us
componenttext: Yes. I know you know this, but we have a very high oil cut in our position with Delaware. This is not a lot of natural gas, a little bit of liquids. This is a big cut that's oil that gives us tremendous economics at the well head and as a result, gives us a really good cash flow to recycle. I don't think that we, today, have a better position to put capital to work as a company and I'd argue that I'm not sure in the industry today call it $50 anyone has a better position on shore than what we've got in the Delaware basin.

componenttext: I appreciate you asking the question. It's one of the things a lot of times that is not well understood because it's not that many moving parts that we are looking for. If you think about trying to be a fairly compartmentalized thinker, in 2016 into '17, they're not that many moving parts that we're looking for in terms of trying to accomplish. And I might let Mitch, if you don't' mind elaborate on that, but it's not like we're trying to do everything at once. We had a very compartmentalized view of what needs to be done ahead of us.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, with the support of the Mozambican government, we made significant progress during this year really on the important government agreements. The suite of agreements that we term legal and construction framework have been so sliced for the governme
componenttext: Charles, with the support of the Mozambican government, we made significant progress during this year really on the important government agreements. The suite of agreements that we term legal and construction framework have been so sliced for the government, and we expect approval of those in the near term. We're also well advanced with our planning in preparation for reassessment. We submitted our reassessment plan to the government in June. And after a few months of discussions with the government, that plan has been accepted and be, again, with approval of the plan in the near future.  When both of these elements are approved in terms of legal and professional framework and reassessment plan, then progress further the -- that our buyers conversing our hedge of agreement to sales and parts agreements, and we'll also take forward all the arrangements for project finance. So our immediate priority just now is to gain approval of the suite of agreements and reassessment plan, and that will progress towards FID.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful detail, Mitch. And if I could ask you as a follow up, going back to your theme of the 3Ds, I feel like a lot of the discussions have been around the DJ and the Delaware. But I wonder if you could talk about the prospects to apply mo
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful detail, Mitch. And if I could ask you as a follow up, going back to your theme of the 3Ds, I feel like a lot of the discussions have been around the DJ and the Delaware. But I wonder if you could talk about the prospects to apply more investment to your international deepwater portfolio. My impression is that exploration projects, such as what you have going on in Colombia don't necessarily yield to increased investment, but maybe that's -- maybe you have a different point of view. And/or alternatively, the opportunities for you guys to replicate the kind of deal you did with FCS, either in the Gulf of Mexico or somewhere else in the world.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if I could just maybe use the comment sort of in a broad sense. We don't look at exploration as sources in the near term for production. Really, our exploration activities are option value for the future, and as a result, we really do see things tha
componenttext: Well, if I could just maybe use the comment sort of in a broad sense. We don't look at exploration as sources in the near term for production. Really, our exploration activities are option value for the future, and as a result, we really do see things that we're doing today in Colombia as having option value. Now once we determine whether or not we have a commercial opportunity, we want go to development then we start to figure out where it is in the queue over a time horizon for production. But the reason for a lot of the answers today about where we put incremental capital, when you've got the positions that we do on shore on the Delaware and the DJ, that provides us extremely attractive rates of return and it also gives us a type of on-site growth that we find very attractive from a standpoint of how we enhance shareholder value. Longer term, we need to continue to find ways to look for new opportunities. What we see in Colombia excites us, both in terms of what we're currently drilling as well as what we see ourselves to the balance of the decade. So that option value is something that we'll continue to look for. There are other places and certainly the Gulf of Mexico, as you made reference to the FCX deal, I don't know if there's another one of the corner. Bob, Glenn and a lot of people did a really good job with that one. We're certainly in business as there are other people that kind of Gulf of Mexico now is attractive as we do. We'd be happy to try to buy some more assets for 1.5x next year's cash flow.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, as you've probably had more conversations with people on that than I have, I can honestly tell you no one's ever had that conversation with me. So it'd be pure conjecture on my part. I don't know that I even could come close to telling you whether o
componenttext: Dave, as you've probably had more conversations with people on that than I have, I can honestly tell you no one's ever had that conversation with me. So it'd be pure conjecture on my part. I don't know that I even could come close to telling you whether or not I have a view on that. I know that when we executed the 10% working interest sale down, it was a part of the playbook that we did not want that much working interest if we were to take FID. Again, I sound like a broken record this morning, but Bob Glenn did a great job selling that down to ONGC. As a result, today, we still, even with all the capital we've spent in Mozambique, if you just think of it at the project level basis, we're still $300-plus million to the positive in terms of what we've invested there versus what we've taken in. So consequently, again on a project level basis, we've done a pretty darn good job of managing our exposure from a cash or capital perspective and still give ourselves a lot of option value over and whether or not we take FID. If someone decides that they like it better than we do or they see more value than we do, we're not married to it anymore are we married to any other asset of our portfolio. But we do believe today that we have those skills, capability, and we also believe the opportunity if we take it to FID for it to be a game changer for our company. And so consequently, Mitch looks at this every day with a very balanced view of what's best for Anadarko in the next decade.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Cool. On another consideration that descript in the DJ with assets up and doing longer laterals has been important in developing all the oil place. Can you talk to us about the ability to draw a longer letter as opposed to single section laterals could in been kind of the pattern on your assets and the likelihood of swaps?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, I mean, that play on a [indiscernible] it's not just one particular zone. As many talked about this morning, it's a stack pay off opportunity, and consequently, there's lots of things that we're looking today that will be a part of the
componenttext: Well, as you know, I mean, that play on a [indiscernible] it's not just one particular zone. As many talked about this morning, it's a stack pay off opportunity, and consequently, there's lots of things that we're looking today that will be a part of the future. But the one thing that we're working on most is the Wolfcamp. So just focusing on the Wolfcamp, yes, we would love, as these things start to settle out in the Delaware Basin, thinking about blocking up with people and making it a little more attractive. Given the velocity of change in the basin, it makes it a little more difficult today. So I think sort of just in the evolution of the basin's development, it's unlikely we're going to see people doing what we did in the DJ with noble and doing so made us a win-win for both of us. But I'm sure Darrell at his folks, Brad and others have been trying. It's early in the evolution or lifecycle of the basin's development.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, this is Darrell. There's no doubt we have better economics as we get into the longer laterals. And I think if you look at the program this year, more than 60% of our wells were in excess of 7,500 foot laterals. And so we have done trade to give us t
componenttext:
Dave, this is Darrell. There's no doubt we have better economics as we get into the longer laterals. And I think if you look at the program this year, more than 60% of our wells were in excess of 7,500 foot laterals. And so we have done trade to give us the ability and we continue to work trades. Some of them aren't big enough to come out and talk in the market, but those things are happening every day. To Al's point, it's not always easy because somebody's leases can be burdened in different way, so we've got to work through that. But I think it's in everyone's best interest to do that, and we're finding a lot of people cooperating. So we'll continue to work it because, again, in an ideal world, we're going to be drilling 10,000-foot laterals. It's better economics. 
How much of your acreage now is single section on? I guess I'm trying to think about a split of [indiscernible] to longer lateral available.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know that I have that exact number. Like I said, there are more than 60% of our wells this year being drilled or in excess of 7,500. So I don't know that it's important where we are today as much as it will be where we're going in getting som
componenttext: Yes. I don't know that I have that exact number. Like I said, there are more than 60% of our wells this year being drilled or in excess of 7,500. So I don't know that it's important where we are today as much as it will be where we're going in getting some of these trades consummated.

componenttext: Congrats, John. And quick question on the Delaware Basin. You got a JV partner out there. How does that partner's goals align with your goals? How does capital allocation work? Is that a relationship that's built to last? Or are there ways around that relationship?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's certainly an atypical relationship in a sense that our partner there stepped into the position by virtue of acquisition they made from Chesapeake. Consequently, it wasn't like this was contemplated day 1 that we would be in a joint venture toge
componenttext: Well, it's certainly an atypical relationship in a sense that our partner there stepped into the position by virtue of acquisition they made from Chesapeake. Consequently, it wasn't like this was contemplated day 1 that we would be in a joint venture together. So far, I have nothing but compliments to pass along and Shell has been a good partner. We've talked to them on many locations about things that we can do and improve efficiencies out here, and I think they've been very receptive. So I wouldn't paint them with a brush that they are major and the consequently unable to understand how hard is value from the Delaware Basin.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then a follow up on exploration. In a sense, you've got a fairly obvious runway of high returns in the DJ and in the Delaware and in tiebacks in the Deepwater Gulf. And when you're going out doing pure exploration, are you incented to go
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then a follow up on exploration. In a sense, you've got a fairly obvious runway of high returns in the DJ and in the Delaware and in tiebacks in the Deepwater Gulf. And when you're going out doing pure exploration, are you incented to go sort of high risk, high rewards? So in other words, if you discover a fairly middling discovery, it might compete for capital but a big blockbuster would. Does that guide your exploration strategy?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our exploration strategy has always been one where we want to make sure we're taking opportunities 2 to give ourselves a chance of things that are near movers. I think that's what we've historically done. I think we'll continue to do that. We have
componenttext: I think our exploration strategy has always been one where we want to make sure we're taking opportunities 2 to give ourselves a chance of things that are near movers. I think that's what we've historically done. I think we'll continue to do that. We have 16 million acres offshore Colombia because we see a lot of prospects activity there and a lot of running room if we're correct. So I think philosophically, the types of things that we will do at exploration, whether it's in the Gulf of Mexico or internationally, are fairly similar. And the Gulf of Mexico today, given the price environment that we're in, if we don't have tieback to existing infrastructure, we're not trying out trying to drill opportunities that require greenfield development as a result. So that may be where the 2 were a little bit different because we're dealing with a much higher cost per well. Typically, we're in a pre-salt environment where the exploration opportunities. Whereas in many cases, internationally, we're post-salt. We're the cost to drill the wells substantially less and so, therefore, if we're successful, the development drilling associated with any development opportunity in a little more economically positive from the standpoint of the price environment. So now I don't think, from a standpoint of Anadarko's view of exploration or my hope for what we're able to deliver on exploration is any different today than it would have been in 2013 or '14 in a different price environment.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, best of luck to you. There's a reason you won that IR Award most full year for Best IR. You may drop this, so we appreciate all the help you've given us over the years and best of luck. Al, going to the DJ. I want to talk about this. If I just look
componenttext: John, best of luck to you. There's a reason you won that IR Award most full year for Best IR. You may drop this, so we appreciate all the help you've given us over the years and best of luck. Al, going to the DJ. I want to talk about this. If I just look at your production over the -- just over the last year, you all kind of flattish [indiscernible] in gas have continued to grow. So I guess a two-part question. One, should we see that reverse as the rig counts are to climb again or is that just a function of the slowdown or drilling it from a gas geowaters climbing in the out years? And then second, I know some of the other operators may have potential issues next summer as far as really flying pressures more in that the CP the middle to the upper part of the basin. How do you guys -- I assume you're okay with your infrastructure, given what you did a few years prior, but how would you answer those 2 questions?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as you look in the next year, we don't see a problem like being advantages to last and drilling in the Southern Horn. We've got White Cliffs, we've got access out of the basin, we've got plants. We're in pretty good shape. So we don't actuall
componenttext: Yes. I think as you look in the next year, we don't see a problem like being advantages to last and drilling in the Southern Horn. We've got White Cliffs, we've got access out of the basin, we've got plants. We're in pretty good shape. So we don't actually see any of those pressures that you're talking about. In terms of the well count, then -- and maybe the oil ratio, I do think you're seeing the impact of the lack of capital spend this year in Wattenberg. And so as the field continues to produce, it does go to a higher GOR. And generally, we've been able to offset as we brought in and drill more wells and put new wells on because they are higher oil cut. So if you just think about, we went 2 quarters in a row with 1 rig, so we don't have a lot of new production coming on. I will have to say that the field guys did a fantastic job hitting the records they did. Yes, a lot of it was gas, but I can tell you that the peek we had in the third quarter after such activity was a fantastic accomplishment on their part. But as we stand up more rigs, and we bring more wells online, you're going to see that turn and again and you should start seeing our oil production go up. It may not be by year-end or even first quarter, but I think we would anticipate next year to reverse that trend, and you'll see the oil production start rising again.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Maybe a couple details on the Permian. Can you talk a little bit -- we talked about some of our longer laterals. Where do you see it in terms of the productivity increases on the longer laterals? Should we expect some of the kinds laterals up versus what you communicated on the singles? And then maybe for spacing in the Wolfcamp. What are you currently assuming kind of the best case in the Wolfcamp spacing? And then what are you currently testing? I know you're talking about going deeper into the Lower Wolfcamp. I mean, where do you think we may eventually go in terms of oil per unit in the Wolfcamp there?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to figure out where I want to start on there. With these laterals, I mean, yes, we're going to be pushing to do those. But some of the things that are increasing our EUR has to do with the type of completions we're doing at onetime or standard
componenttext: I'm trying to figure out where I want to start on there. With these laterals, I mean, yes, we're going to be pushing to do those. But some of the things that are increasing our EUR has to do with the type of completions we're doing at onetime or standard completion was sort of 1,400 pounds per foot. Today, I would call that standard completion 2,500 pounds per foot. And I can tell you we're experimenting with the sand and water rates double that. So we're not sure where that's going to go. We probably have more to deliver or more to talk about in March, but we are seeing the increasing EURs as we continue to put more sand and water. And so we'll see where that no return is on that, but we're seen good things right now. And that's really because of our increasing EURs at this point. It's just the change of our completions. I think your second question was?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: On spacing on the Wolfcamp. Where do you think you -- we may eventually go in terms of how many wells are you able to put into a unit at Wolfcamp? What are you testing right now?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're doing a number of test. We've got a 20 well test going. And so a lot of that is going to be driven by economics and to the extent you have interference. So I think it's just too early to tell right now. Because, again, if you look at how we're
componenttext: Well, we're doing a number of test. We've got a 20 well test going. And so a lot of that is going to be driven by economics and to the extent you have interference. So I think it's just too early to tell right now. Because, again, if you look at how we're drilling these wells, we're not doing too many tests where there's big clusters. We do have the 120 well of test going on that should give us a lot of information. And again, I would say by March, hopefully, we've got more to tell you on that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

Maybe the path of potential of FID? And if you take kind of standalone development like Shenandoah really compete with the buyback opportunities you have in the Gulf? And then I'll leave it there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Darrell. We have a couple of competing options there, so we're really in the pre-FID. We're at a point to make FID election at this point, but we felt that overall, the semi-sub was going to garnish us a little bit more flexibility in what th
componenttext: Yes. This is Darrell. We have a couple of competing options there, so we're really in the pre-FID. We're at a point to make FID election at this point, but we felt that overall, the semi-sub was going to garnish us a little bit more flexibility in what that answer look like. So we decided just go down to the one option as we continue our pre-FID efforts. But we're far from making FID decision today. We'll be look at drilling that 6 wells here. By the end of the year, we'll be getting on it. So we look forward to seeing those results.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it'd be fair to say that as we contemplate mentioning Shenandoah, there will be on what we can do with a margin with the capital. And it'll be an allocation like it would be for anything where we're looking what the rate of return is as well as th
componenttext: I think it'd be fair to say that as we contemplate mentioning Shenandoah, there will be on what we can do with a margin with the capital. And it'll be an allocation like it would be for anything where we're looking what the rate of return is as well as the cash-on-cash return. A lot of times, our insurers are very focused on rate of return and not cash-on-cash because as everybody knows on this call, it's great to have an internal rate of return. It's 50%. But if you get the cash back in the year and you're pretty much done, that's a hard trend mill to continue. So we want a cocktail our mix that gives us really good rates of return with really good cash-on-cash characteristics. So there could be a role that Shenandoah or another option like that place in our portfolio. So I don't want to leave people with the view that location of capital is purely an IRR-driven derivative. Consequently, we a portfolio to run and we'll consider whether or not at the time of sanctioning it, it makes sense to commercially develop Shenandoah with our partners or not.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not there yet. We're just finishing up our program in West Africa right now, and we expect the rig will be demobilizing from that prospect over there. Get to Colombia within the next month or so. We've got a 2-well program set up there. We're making
componenttext: We're not there yet. We're just finishing up our program in West Africa right now, and we expect the rig will be demobilizing from that prospect over there. Get to Colombia within the next month or so. We've got a 2-well program set up there. We're making strides in reducing the time to drill the well in Colombia after our initial campaign, so the next well we'll get to will actually top set the first well and go over to drill a Purple Angel Well, and that's probably going to be about a 45-day well, give or take a few days. And as we carry into the new year in 2017, we'll move over and drill another prospect in the similar section. They're called [indiscernible] . So they're not long wells. We're continuing to get up the learning curve on drilling wells in Colombia, and we look forward to seeing those results. But what I would remind you of a little bit is we're really looking forward to getting over to the cool area where we shot the 30,000 square kilometers of 3D, and we've just got a fast-track volume in looking for the final volume in by the end of next year. And our goal is really to accelerate drilling activity over in that big chunk of acreage in the Ultra Deepwater offshore of Colombia. Looking for oil, of course, there. And very hopeful that we've got Rock and buried a little bit deeper, so we're anxious to get over there on that particular acreage.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I've been at natural gas bear for quite awhile. I think we always thought the gas will find its way up around $3 then we find the ceiling there. To a large extent, that's been correct. I mean, we always believe around $3 that there is just an impedi
componenttext: Well, I've been at natural gas bear for quite awhile. I think we always thought the gas will find its way up around $3 then we find the ceiling there. To a large extent, that's been correct. I mean, we always believe around $3 that there is just an impediment from a demand standpoint for now. But I think you also reason a lot of people. In January we talked about selling our natural gas properties and people kind of looked that on a cross side that we would actually have a market for it. There's been a lot of very successful private equity people that have taken a view on natural gas and done quite well with it. I think for a company like ours that has the assets that we do and our access to oil and liquids that we do, consequently, it's not really in our best interest to pursue natural gas. It doesn't give us the same wellhead margin. It doesn't give us the same ability to scalability. And the returns, coupled with the scalability, just always tilt in the favor of the DJ and the Delaware for us. John, I just have to say, I don't mind being wrong, but I think our view is that it would take natural gas to approach $6 before we would probably displace our interest investing in oil. I don't see that happening.

componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Darrell. I would say not. To the contrary, I think as the year went on, we were pleasantly surprised that we're able to get some of the service cost down a little bit. Now I think that's leveling out. But as we've stood up more rigs and contr
componenttext: Yes. This is Darrell. I would say not. To the contrary, I think as the year went on, we were pleasantly surprised that we're able to get some of the service cost down a little bit. Now I think that's leveling out. But as we've stood up more rigs and contracted more equipment, we're not really seeing that pressure today. So my guess is as oil continues to go up, I think it's up around $60, we may see some of that. But I think there's enough equipments still on the ground and crews willing to work and get part of the business that we're not going to see that pressure for awhile.

componenttext: Now I would tell you that we're very pleased with what's happening there at Jubilee. We're continuing the work through the third issue, but the shuttle tanker system that they setup is working well and we're on our way to try to get to a permanent fix. We're still trying to get a temporary fix done by the end of the year. But I would say all-in-all, the activity there are going as well as we would've expected.

componenttext: Well, we're very fortunate to have liquids in the system, so you're right for highlighting that. I do think those are commercial decision will likely hinge on just the type of gas contract we could enter into. Because without that, the oil becomes a by-product. You really need to be able to move the gas into a market out of price that's attractive in order to evacuate the liquids.

componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Darrell. Well, I can tell it was a disappointment. But probably more than that, it was really a surprise. I mean, based on the reprocess side that we have, we fully expected this to be good. So it's sort of hurts some northern into that field
componenttext: Yes. This is Darrell. Well, I can tell it was a disappointment. But probably more than that, it was really a surprise. I mean, based on the reprocess side that we have, we fully expected this to be good. So it's sort of hurts some northern into that field. I can tell you consequently, we've -- we're sidetracking that well now close to the Discovery well. So we know it's good there. And so the thought there is so we'll complete this well we have on first quarter. So we really see little impact in '17 from a volume standpoint, but we got to remap this thing and try to better understand it. It may have a reserve impact, and we'll work through that before the end of the year. But I think as part as we're concerned, we don't see an impairment on our side based on our investment here. But it was truly a disappointment and a real surprise as to this being wet there. So it sort of takes away from the northern end of the field, but we're still very high on the south end of the field and high in the Burg as well. So that will be future wells.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Darrell's right. Just take one other comment. Yes, we've been surprised by it, but I will say we're defining ourselves as having to take a reserve right now, it will be very modest. The reason we've not impaired today, if you recall we promoted out th
componenttext: And Darrell's right. Just take one other comment. Yes, we've been surprised by it, but I will say we're defining ourselves as having to take a reserve right now, it will be very modest. The reason we've not impaired today, if you recall we promoted out the development of drilling here, so our cost basis here is a lot different than our partners. And, therefore, in addition to the cost bases, we also have the advantage of carried from an impairment standpoint reserve adjustment if one is needed So in the scheme of things from us, it's a very small adjustment if it turns out to be that's the case.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I've said at the start, it's a bittersweet day. We had a great quarter. A lot of people have done a wonderful amount of work this quarter and this year for what has been a very turbulent period in our industry's colorful history. But we are going
componenttext:
Well, as I've said at the start, it's a bittersweet day. We had a great quarter. A lot of people have done a wonderful amount of work this quarter and this year for what has been a very turbulent period in our industry's colorful history. But we are going to miss John. He's done, as I said earlier, a tremendous job. He's been a leader. He's been someone who, I think, has taken our industry in terms of how Investor Relations should be conveyed and conducted to a level that has not been, in my estimation, done previously. It was a pleasure for the 10 years of he's been on the job to work with him, and we have every confidence that he has got Robin ready to go. And as they say in East Texas, she is sitting and go and we're ready for her to step in the job that have gone before her. So it's bittersweet today. We're all going to miss John, but I will promise you, she is a capable of stepping in as he's trained here quite well and she's very capable in her own regards. 
So John, we're going to miss you. 
And Robin, we look forward to working with you next quarter. 
And thank you, everybody, for today. We'll talk to you soon. Bye-bye.

componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to John Colglazier. Plea
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note, today's event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to John Colglazier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, thanks, Rocco, and good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for our third quarter conference call. I'd like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financial measures, and a nu
componenttext:
Oh, thanks, Rocco, and good morning, everyone. We're glad you could join us today for our third quarter conference call. I'd like to remind you that today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financial measures, and a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discuss today. So I encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and the GAAP reconciliations located on our website and attached to yesterday's earnings release. In just a moment, I'll turn the call over to Al Walker for some brief opening remarks. 
And as most of you know, after 41 quarterly calls, 10 investor conferences or updates, I'm retiring from Anadarko, and today is my last day in Investor Relations. I've had a great time working with the company over the years, and especially working with you guys on -- over the course of my 10 years here in Investor Relations. I'm very confident in passing the baton to Robin Fielder who, along with Peter Zagrzecki; and the newest member of the IR team, Jim Grant, a geoscientist, who is replacing Shandell Szabo who was recently promoted to Vice President in our onshore group. These folks are more than capable of continuing to provide the level of service that you've come to expect from us. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Al.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John. It's a bittersweet morning, but we achieved a lot in the first 3 quarters of 2016 and positioned the company well. And we've also positioned the portfolio for the future, with our assets in the Delaware, DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Me
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John. It's a bittersweet morning, but we achieved a lot in the first 3 quarters of 2016 and positioned the company well. And we've also positioned the portfolio for the future, with our assets in the Delaware, DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico serving as the primary sources for our growth. 
As a result, we're increasing our anticipated divestiture adjusted sales volumes for the year by 8 million BOE from the midpoint of our initial expectations, continuing to make significant reductions in our cost structure, expecting to now close more than $4 billion of monetizations this year and projecting to finish the year with more than $2.5 billion of cash on hand. 
Operationally, we've accelerated activity by adding 2 rigs in the Delaware Basin of West Texas. The company's made great strides to enhance the economics of our premier position in this world-class oil play. This has been achieved by further cost reductions, while incorporating an enhanced completion design that's increased our EURs to more than 1 million BOE per well, which enjoyed a very high oil cut. 
With our increased rig activity, we will continue to rapidly evaluate the stack pay potential across our almost 600,000 gross acres in this position. And as we move to start the development program for next year, we're quite excited.
In Colorado, the DJ Basin also added 2 rigs, and that has been done during the quarter. Our organization has done a fantastic job of driving savings and efficiencies here as well, enabling us to deliver more for less. As a result of these savings, we will reinvest this capital and drill 90 more wells, complete 50 additional wells; and with -- combined with our base optimization, we will provide more than 5 million BOE of additional production well above our expectations. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, Lucius continues to outperform, achieving a daily record of over 100,000-plus barrels of oil per day. This, along with new production from our development wells at K2 and Caesar/Tonga, increased our year-over-year oil volumes in the Gulf of Mexico by 10,000 barrels per day to 65,000 barrels per day. 
And as we announced last month, upon closing the acquisition of Freeport McMoRan's Gulf of Mexico assets, we expect to double production in the Gulf of Mexico to about 160,000 BOE per day, 85% of which is comprised of oil. We will plan to use a portion of the $4 billion of cash that we will have at quarter end to fund our acquisition and redeem the remaining $750 million of senior notes due September of 2017. As noted in last night's news release, we also expect to receive in excess of $1 billion of proceeds from the pending divestiture of our Carthage assets in East Texas. 
Our monetization program has significantly exceeded expectations as we streamlined our portfolio and materially strengthened the financial position of our company. We are increasingly more focused and competitive as a result. And as mentioned, our expectations continue accelerating our activities in the Delaware, the DJ, as well as growing the Gulf of Mexico, in an effort to improve the production and the investment of our company. This should result in delivering oil production with a combined compounded annual rate of return over the next 5 years that will show very strong double-digit growth.
Our employees have done an outstanding job of ensuring that we enhance value in the near term, and now, well into the future. I want to thank each of them for the long hours and hard work that have resulted in having Anadarko be very favorably positioned, given the operating  environment in the last 2 years.
And before I turn it to Q&A, I also want to express my appreciation from the board, from management and all of the Anadarko employees for the years of tireless effort John has provided to us and to our shareholders. John, you've done a few -- a lot of things a few can, and you'll be greatly missed. These calls won't be quite the same, but we will always remember those things that you did to make everything at Anadarko go so well on mornings when sometimes it just didn't seem to go as usually as it could have. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Today's first question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Al, I wanted to start a little bit in the Delaware. We saw pretty punchy evaluation for the Silver Hill asset packet and Loving and Winkler, with the transaction, I think, setting [ph] more than 40,000 per acre. I was wondering, first, if you could remind
componenttext: Al, I wanted to start a little bit in the Delaware. We saw pretty punchy evaluation for the Silver Hill asset packet and Loving and Winkler, with the transaction, I think, setting [ph] more than 40,000 per acre. I was wondering, first, if you could remind us of your acreage position in Loving. And if you could discuss your broader delineation efforts beyond the Wolfcamp A, because clearly, the industry's pretty excited about the stock pay potential in the Delaware.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Arun, thank you. I might have Darrell help me a little bit with some of the questions you have. But let me just say, as we looked at Silver Hill, and obviously you know the geography quite well. You know they're right next door to us in terms of how
componenttext: Well, Arun, thank you. I might have Darrell help me a little bit with some of the questions you have. But let me just say, as we looked at Silver Hill, and obviously you know the geography quite well. You know they're right next door to us in terms of how their acreage is very close. As I've looked at how these acreage values have increasingly gone to places I would never have imagined. I mean, we're paying -- or seeing people, rather, pay price per acre today that exceeded acreage values when oil was over $100. And so consequently, I think we have a little bit of pause around just the valuations and how certain of these have escalated in places. I think as we've talked to you about Mormont, the rock that we have and the Tier 1 acreage position that we're fortunate enough to be able to enjoy, have given us a lot to be proud of. Now it's not just the Wolfcamp, as you've heard us talk about in a lot of occasions. It's in addition to the Wolfcamp, the Avalons, the Bone Spring. And as a result, we have a lot here. And so maybe rather than having me explain things in detail, I'll have Darrell do so. But I will just comment lastly, and it relates to just M&A in the Delaware portion. I don't think we're done. I mean, I think I saw something from one of our competitors that said that we might see $100,000 values per acre out here pretty soon. I'm not sure if I can imagine that, but I also can't believe that we're double where we were in 2014 on a per acre basis either. So, Darrell?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just start with saying most of the acreage we have we do feel as Tier 1. And when you look at Loving County, and we finally have half our acreage sitting in Loving and we actually think that's the best of the best. So we're very content in wha
componenttext: Yes. Let me just start with saying most of the acreage we have we do feel as Tier 1. And when you look at Loving County, and we finally have half our acreage sitting in Loving and we actually think that's the best of the best. So we're very content in what we have. When you think about what else is there outside the Wolfcamp, and we recognize those things and we keep quoting numbers on the Wolfcamp, and that's because we think that's the largest price, not that the other ones won't contribute to our bottom line overtime. But if you go back to the offshore port, you can see on Page 6 some of the -- because of our acreage position being as large as it is, we're continuing to spend time to make sure we understand the Wolfcamp -- particularly the Wolfcamp A, it's the -- it's by far the best zone because it has a number of benches in it. We're not discounting the Avalon and Bone Springs. We think they have a lot of potential. But at this point, we're going to some of the deeper depths and testing that first. So we'll get to that, eventually. But right now, we're really focused on exploiting the Wolfcamp and understanding exactly what we have in our position. And we've been pretty pleased as to what we've found to date.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's fair question. As we continue to talk more about the fact that we see the Delaware, the DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico being our growth regions, I think in that cascading word I just gave you, that's where we would put incremental dollars
componenttext: Well, it's fair question. As we continue to talk more about the fact that we see the Delaware, the DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico being our growth regions, I think in that cascading word I just gave you, that's where we would put incremental dollars to work, would be Delaware, DJ, deepwater Gulf of Mexico. Our ability to redeploy some of the capital and cash that I talked about in my prepared remarks, if we additionally have cash beyond that, I don't think that would change the cueing.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, John, you'll be missed, and congratulations to Robin in the new role. My first question is really a follow-up to the last one. Is there a limit on how much you will sell? I mean, there seems to be large portions of your portfolio that mig
componenttext: Congratulations, John, you'll be missed, and congratulations to Robin in the new role. My first question is really a follow-up to the last one. Is there a limit on how much you will sell? I mean, there seems to be large portions of your portfolio that might not compete for capital versus the 3Ds here. And maybe can you just explore what are your limits for redeployment in the core areas? And is there -- if asset sales exceed that amount, is there a buyback scenario beyond the investment potential?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think today as we project what we're going to be trying to do over the coming years, the ability to invest in the Delaware, the DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico gives us exceptional rates of return, assuming oil prices are about where they are,
componenttext: Well, I think today as we project what we're going to be trying to do over the coming years, the ability to invest in the Delaware, the DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico gives us exceptional rates of return, assuming oil prices are about where they are, if not a little bit higher. Obviously, if we pull back the $25 a share -- or $25 per barrel rather, that'll have an impact upon our investing. How we will deploy capital at that point, I think we would reconsider. We can't tell you today that we have an answer for that per se, other than we'd spend less. I think we've been very diligent about trying to stay within cash inflows with the way in which we invest and not put our balance sheet at risk. But I'm not really sure today that we see if there's a finite concern associated with investing in the Delaware, the DJ in particular, with respect to having an abundance of cash as long as we're in a $50 to $60 oil price world. So assuming that for a moment, I think you can continue to expect that we will reposition our portfolio more towards oil and away from natural gas, particularly dry grass, and that we believe it compete -- there's inability within our portfolio for dry gas to compete for capital, given what we have in the Delaware, the DJ and the deepwater Gulf of Mexico. And it's not really that we are naysayers on natural gas, it's just we're the beneficiaries in extremely attractive position in both the Delaware and the DJ onshore. And as we like to remind people, and I'm sure you're well aware of this, if we happen to be a little wrong and natural gas prices go up higher than anticipated, it just makes the Delaware and DJ investments worth even more than what we had originally expected it to be with a more modest outlook for natural gas.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think I understand that. And then -- and secondly, the substantially raised the 4Q production guidance on an apples-to-apples basis, 32,000 barrels a day. But is the lift there enhanced completions and how much is activity? Maybe just walk us thro
componenttext: Okay. I think I understand that. And then -- and secondly, the substantially raised the 4Q production guidance on an apples-to-apples basis, 32,000 barrels a day. But is the lift there enhanced completions and how much is activity? Maybe just walk us through the color and why the U.S. gas volumes are up. A little more color to the 4 guides I think would be helpful.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure thing -- it's Colglazier. Yes, we took the midpoint of guidance from divestiture adjusted from the second to the third quarter for the fourth quarter guidance up about 3 million BOEs to your point. A lot of that is in the U.S. activity for the oil, d
componenttext: Sure thing -- it's Colglazier. Yes, we took the midpoint of guidance from divestiture adjusted from the second to the third quarter for the fourth quarter guidance up about 3 million BOEs to your point. A lot of that is in the U.S. activity for the oil, driven by the performance you've seen at Lucius as well, the ongoing impact that we have from our Delaware Basin activities that Darrell talked about. And then we also have the corresponding gas and NGLs up as well, so it's really spread throughout the onshore portfolio. And then as you noticed, we also took out a partial lifting out of Algeria as well just from a timing of tanker liftings out there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think from a high level perspective, if you think about it, we actually set production records not only in Delaware, but in DJ and the Gulf of Mexico this last quarter.
componenttext: I think from a high level perspective, if you think about it, we actually set production records not only in Delaware, but in DJ and the Gulf of Mexico this last quarter.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Leggate of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, there's a lot of scared animals out there. So congratulations, good luck. Guys, I wonder if I could just hit the disposal question again. So Al, one of John's parting comment to us is if it doesn't have a D, it's probably not in the portfolio long t
componenttext: John, there's a lot of scared animals out there. So congratulations, good luck. Guys, I wonder if I could just hit the disposal question again. So Al, one of John's parting comment to us is if it doesn't have a D, it's probably not in the portfolio long term, meaning Delaware, DJ and deepwater. I'm wondering if you could just give us a broader kind of view as [indiscernible] reasonable characterization as to how we should think about the future simplification of Anadarko. And I'm -- I'd also ask you to elaborate on what that means for some of the noncore international assets. And then I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we keep trying to focus investors on the idea that, in the near term, growth and the deployment of capital are focused on those 3 areas you made reference to. It's not that we think that that's the only place we're going to make investments
componenttext: Well, I think we keep trying to focus investors on the idea that, in the near term, growth and the deployment of capital are focused on those 3 areas you made reference to. It's not that we think that that's the only place we're going to make investments and take consideration in the future, simply because a lot of our exploration, as you know better than most, Doug, is there for option value. So it's very important that we continue to take opportunities where we think it's a good risk rate of return opportunity to simply look for places where we may be able to have option value in the future. Colombia could be just that. Mozambique continue to be just that. It's not requiring much capital, neither one are that capital-intensive at this point, but it gives us option guide for the future. But I think the point we're trying to make is that we are and have been, for most of the last 1.5 years, consistently explaining that we're moving away from natural gas as a focus for investing. We're moving into oil and liquids concentrated opportunities, and that we're trying to simplify the way we think about, particularly our onshore business. And that means that our focus then is going to go into 2 particular place, the Delaware and the DJ Basin, simply because they provide us the best rates of return within our portfolio that compete for capital better than anything else that we have. And we believe if -- maybe we're just a little bit biased in this, but we believe it creates the best rates of return in our industry for onshore assets. So we have industry-leading assets, we believe, within our portfolio. We also think that for the allocation of capital, the return associated with that, the focus on those 3 areas is particularly important in order to show growth. And that growth will largely be oil growth in the coming years through the balance of the decade.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the clarification. I guess, I'll now point my follow-up is an exploration question and it's -- we've now had a couple of well results, I guess, in Côthe d'Ivoire. You haven't really elaborated much on your plans for an asset that you still c
componenttext: I appreciate the clarification. I guess, I'll now point my follow-up is an exploration question and it's -- we've now had a couple of well results, I guess, in Côthe d'Ivoire. You haven't really elaborated much on your plans for an asset that you still carry a very large working interest in. So I just wondered if you could give us an update as to your thoughts on how that potential project moves forward?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've seen, through the ops report and some of the commentary we provided, we've had good exploration success there. I think the reason that we've not gone beyond that is we're still trying to understand what we believe to be the commercial
componenttext: Well, I think you've seen, through the ops report and some of the commentary we provided, we've had good exploration success there. I think the reason that we've not gone beyond that is we're still trying to understand what we believe to be the commercial solution for the discoveries we've had. And in particular, for the natural gas associated with the Paon potential development. I think once we have an understanding of the commerciality of that play, we'll talk more about the development. But at this juncture, I would describe the success we've had as quite good, but that does not correlate yet into a commercial discussion until we have a gas contract that we believe, in fact, gives us that development opportunity. And so that may be the missing link, Doug, that you're seeing as a part of the narrative from us.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold with RBC
